dn33:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā mallesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi yena pāvā nāma mallānaṃ nagaraṃ tadavasari.
dn33:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Mallas together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a Mallian town named Pāvā.
dn33:1.1.2.comm: This discourse picks up from DN 29:17.1, where the Buddha urges that the Sangha should gather and recite the Dhamma for the long lasting of the dispensation. There he lists the 37 factors of awakening, a standard early collation of practice-oriented teachings that are primarily collected in the Mahāvagga of the Saṁyutta Nikāya. This discourse is a late one, and appears to be an initial attempt to compile a more thorough list of the Buddha’s teachings. The Sarvāstivāda version of the same discourse formed the basis of one of their seven Abhidhamma books, the Sangītiparyāya.

dn33:1.1.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā pāvāyaṃ viharati cundassa kammāraputtassa ambavane.
dn33:1.1.3.eng: There he stayed in Cunda the smith’s mango grove.
dn33:1.1.3.comm: At AN 10.176 Cunda asks about the purity of the western brahmins; at DN 16:4.13.5 = Ud 8.5 he offers the Buddha’s last meal; at Snp 1.5 he asks about a true ascetic.

dn33:1.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pāveyyakānaṃ mallānaṃ ubbhatakaṃ nāma navaṃ sandhāgāraṃ acirakāritaṃ hoti anajjhāvuṭṭhaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenaci vā manussabhūtena.
dn33:1.2.1.eng: Now at that time a new town hall named Ubbhaṭaka had recently been constructed for the Mallas of Pāvā. It had not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any human at all.
dn33:1.2.1.comm: The completion of a town hall was celebrated by a talk for the Sakyans SN 35.243:1.2 and MN 53:2.1. Such halls were community meeting places that played a central role in civic society and communal decision-making in democratic republics such as the Mallas and the Sakyans. The Buddha’s participation is a sign of his support for their civic and democratic process.

dn33:1.2.2.pli: Assosuṃ kho pāveyyakā mallā: “bhagavā kira mallesu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi pāvaṃ anuppatto pāvāyaṃ viharati cundassa kammāraputtassa ambavane”ti.
dn33:1.2.2.eng: The Mallas of Pāvā also heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in Cunda’s mango grove.

dn33:1.2.3.pli: Atha kho pāveyyakā mallā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho pāveyyakā mallā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn33:1.2.3.eng: Then they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

dn33:1.2.4.pli: “idha, bhante, pāveyyakānaṃ mallānaṃ ubbhatakaṃ nāma navaṃ sandhāgāraṃ acirakāritaṃ hoti anajjhāvuṭṭhaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā kenaci vā manussabhūtena.
dn33:1.2.4.eng: “Sir, a new town hall named Ubbhaṭaka has recently been constructed for the Mallas of Pāvā. It has not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any human at all.

dn33:1.2.5.pli: Tañca kho, bhante, bhagavā paṭhamaṃ paribhuñjatu, bhagavatā paṭhamaṃ paribhuttaṃ pacchā pāveyyakā mallā paribhuñjissanti.
dn33:1.2.5.eng: May the Buddha be the first to use it, and only then will the Mallas of Pāvā use it.

dn33:1.2.6.pli: Tadassa pāveyyakānaṃ mallānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
dn33:1.2.6.eng: That would be for the lasting welfare and happiness of the Mallas of Pāvā.”

dn33:1.3.1.pli: Atha kho pāveyyakā mallā bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena sandhāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā sabbasanthariṃ sandhāgāraṃ santharitvā bhagavato āsanāni paññāpetvā udakamaṇikaṃ patiṭṭhapetvā telapadīpaṃ āropetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu;
dn33:1.3.1.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, the Mallas got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the new town hall, where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed an oil lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha,

dn33:1.3.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho te pāveyyakā mallā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn33:1.3.3.eng: and told him of their preparations, saying,

dn33:1.3.4.pli: “sabbasantharisanthataṃ, bhante, sandhāgāraṃ, bhagavato āsanāni paññattāni, udakamaṇiko patiṭṭhāpito, telapadīpo āropito.

dn33:1.4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena sandhāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā pāde pakkhāletvā sandhāgāraṃ pavisitvā majjhimaṃ thambhaṃ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisīdi.
dn33:1.4.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the new town hall together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. Having washed his feet he entered the town hall and sat against the central column facing east.

dn33:1.4.2.pli: Bhikkhusaṅghopi kho pāde pakkhāletvā sandhāgāraṃ pavisitvā pacchimaṃ bhittiṃ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisīdi bhagavantaṃyeva purakkhatvā.
dn33:1.4.2.eng: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.

dn33:1.4.3.pli: Pāveyyakāpi kho mallā pāde pakkhāletvā sandhāgāraṃ pavisitvā puratthimaṃ bhittiṃ nissāya pacchimābhimukhā nisīdiṃsu bhagavantaṃyeva purakkhatvā.
dn33:1.4.3.eng: The Mallas of Pāvā also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.

dn33:1.4.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pāveyyake malle bahudeva rattiṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uyyojesi:
dn33:1.4.4.eng: The Buddha spent much of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the Mallas with a Dhamma talk. Then he sent them off,

dn33:1.4.5.comm: As at DN 16:5.19.2, the Mallas are called Vāseṭṭhas after the family lineage of their priest (purohita).

dn33:1.4.7.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho pāveyyakā mallā bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
dn33:1.4.7.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied the Mallas. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

dn33:1.5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantesu pāveyyakesu mallesu tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi:
dn33:1.5.1.eng: Soon after they left, the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent. He addressed Venerable Sāriputta,

dn33:1.5.2.eng: “Sāriputta, the Saṅgha of mendicants is rid of dullness and drowsiness.

dn33:1.5.3.eng: Give them some Dhamma talk as you feel inspired.

dn33:1.5.5.comm: The Buddha likewise mentions his bad back and invites another monk to teach in both the other suttas where he is first to teach in a new hall (MN 53:5.3, SN 35.243:3.4), and also on the uposatha at Naḷakapāna (AN 10.67, AN 10.68). These were all occasions when the community was sitting late into the night.

dn33:1.5.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato paccassosi.

dn33:1.5.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññāpetvā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya, sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasi karitvā.
dn33:1.5.7.eng: And then the Buddha spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.

dn33:1.6.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto pāvāyaṃ adhunākālaṅkato hoti.
dn33:1.6.1.eng: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had recently passed away at Pāvā.
dn33:1.6.1.comm: As at DN 29:1.3 and MN 104:2.1, in both of which the Buddha was in the Sakyan lands at this time. There, the news is conveyed to the Buddha by the novice Cunda. Perhaps he was confused with Cunda the smith.

dn33:1.6.2.pli: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
dn33:1.6.2.eng: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:

dn33:1.6.3.pli: “na tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāsi, ahaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānāmi, kiṃ tvaṃ imaṃ dhammavinayaṃ ājānissasi. Micchāpaṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammāpaṭipanno. Sahitaṃ me, asahitaṃ te. Purevacanīyaṃ pacchā avaca, pacchāvacanīyaṃ pure avaca. Adhiciṇṇaṃ te viparāvattaṃ, āropito te vādo, niggahito tvamasi, cara vādappamokkhāya, nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosī”ti.
dn33:1.6.3.eng: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”

dn33:1.6.4.pli: Vadhoyeva kho maññe nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu vattati.
dn33:1.6.4.eng: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.

dn33:1.6.5.pli: Yepi nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā, tepi nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu nibbinnarūpā virattarūpā paṭivānarūpā, yathā taṃ durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṃvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe.
dn33:1.6.5.eng: And the Jain Ñātika’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.

dn33:1.7.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
dn33:1.7.1.eng: Then Sāriputta told the mendicants about these things. He went on to say,

dn33:1.7.3.pli: tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā …pe… bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe.

dn33:1.7.4.pli: Evañhetaṃ, āvuso, hoti durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṃvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite.
dn33:1.7.4.eng: “That’s what happens, reverends, when a teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.

dn33:1.7.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho panāvuso, amhākaṃ bhagavatā dhammo svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṃvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito.
dn33:1.7.5.eng: But this teaching is well explained and well propounded to us by the Blessed One, emancipating, leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is a fully awakened Buddha.

dn33:1.7.6.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ, na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.7.6.eng: You should all recite this in concert, without disputing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

dn33:1.7.7.pli: Katamo cāvuso, amhākaṃ bhagavatā dhammo svākkhāto suppavedito niyyāniko upasamasaṃvattaniko sammāsambuddhappavedito;

dn33:1.7.8.pli: yattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ, na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ?

dn33:1.7.10.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena eko dhammo sammadakkhāto.
dn33:1.7.10.eng: There are teachings grouped by one that have been rightly explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
dn33:1.7.10.comm: Sāriputta adopts the “Aṅguttara principle” of arranging teachings by number rather than the “Saṁyutta principle” of arrangement by topic. Thus this list of teachings has more in common with the Aṅguttara Nikāya than with the Buddha’s original list of Saṁyutta topics. I note unusual or rare terms, but the references here are meant to be indicative rather than comprehensive.

dn33:1.7.11.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ, na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.7.11.eng: You should all recite these in concert, without disputing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

dn33:1.8.1.eng: What are the teachings grouped by one?

dn33:1.8.2.eng: All sentient beings are sustained by food.
dn33:1.8.2.comm: AN 10.27:10.5, AN 10.28:4.5, Kp 4:1.2. | Compare Bṛhadāranyaka Upaniṣad 5.12.1, “for all these beings are contained in food”, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.11.9, “all these beings live when they partake of food”, Taittirīya Upaniṣad 2.2.1, “any creatures who dwell on earth are produced from food, and by food alone they live.”

dn33:1.8.3.eng: All sentient beings are sustained by conditions.
dn33:1.8.3.comm: This phrase is unique, but here saṅkhārā (“conditions”) is a synonym of āhāra (“food, fuel, nutriment”).

dn33:1.8.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena eko dhammo sammadakkhāto.
dn33:1.8.4.eng: These are the teachings grouped by one that have been rightly explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
dn33:1.8.4.comm: The paucity of teachings of “one” reflects the fact that the Aṅguttara Nikāya Ones consists mostly of longer teachings that have been split into atoms to artificially create “ones”.

dn33:1.8.5.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ, na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.8.5.eng: You should all recite these in concert, without disputing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

dn33:1.9.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dve dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:1.9.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by two that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:1.9.2.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ, na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.9.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:1.9.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by two?

dn33:1.9.5.eng: Ignorance and craving for continued existence.

dn33:1.9.6.eng: Views favoring existence and views favoring nonexistence.

dn33:1.9.9.eng: Being hard to admonish and having bad friends.

dn33:1.9.10.eng: Being easy to admonish and having good friends.

dn33:1.9.11.eng: Skill in offenses and skill in resolving offenses.
dn33:1.9.11.comm: These Vinaya concepts also at AN 2.97:1.3.

dn33:1.9.12.eng: Skill in meditative attainments and skill in emerging from those attainments.

dn33:1.9.13.eng: Skill in the elements and skill in application of mind.

dn33:1.9.14.eng: Skill in the sense fields and skill in dependent origination.

dn33:1.9.15.eng: Skill in what is possible and skill in what is impossible.

dn33:1.9.20.eng: Lack of mindfulness and lack of situational awareness.

dn33:1.9.22.pli: Indriyesu aguttadvāratā ca bhojane amattaññutā ca.
dn33:1.9.22.eng: Not guarding the sense doors and eating too much.

dn33:1.9.23.pli: Indriyesu guttadvāratā ca bhojane mattaññutā ca.
dn33:1.9.23.eng: Guarding the sense doors and moderation in eating.

dn33:1.9.24.eng: The power of reflection and the power of development.

dn33:1.9.25.eng: The power of mindfulness and the power of immersion.

dn33:1.9.27.eng: The basis of serenity and the basis of exertion.
dn33:1.9.27.comm: Samathanimitta at SN 46.2:14.2 and SN 46.51:11.2; paggahanimitta at AN 3.102.

dn33:1.9.29.eng: Failure in ethics and failure in view.

dn33:1.9.30.eng: Accomplishment in ethics and accomplishment in view.

dn33:1.9.31.eng: Purification of ethics and purification of view.

dn33:1.9.32.pli: Diṭṭhivisuddhi kho pana yathā diṭṭhissa ca padhānaṃ.
dn33:1.9.32.eng: Purification of view and making an effort in line with that view.

dn33:1.9.33.pli: Saṃvego ca saṃvejanīyesu ṭhānesu saṃviggassa ca yoniso padhānaṃ.
dn33:1.9.33.eng: Inspiration, and making a suitable effort when inspired by inspiring places.

dn33:1.9.34.pli: Asantuṭṭhitā ca kusalesu dhammesu appaṭivānitā ca padhānasmiṃ.
dn33:1.9.34.eng: To never be content with skillful qualities, and to never stop trying.

dn33:1.9.36.eng: Knowledge of ending and knowledge of non-arising.
dn33:1.9.36.comm: “Knowledge of ending” (khaye ñāṇaṁ) refers to the aggregates; it is discussed at SN 12.23. | “Knowledge of non-arising” (anuppāde ñāṇaṁ) is the knowledge that one will not be born again.

dn33:1.9.37.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dve dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:1.9.37.eng: These are the teachings grouped by two that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:1.9.38.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ, na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.9.38.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:1.10.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tayo dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:1.10.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by three that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:1.10.2.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.10.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:1.10.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by three?

dn33:1.10.5.pli: lobho akusalamūlaṃ, doso akusalamūlaṃ, moho akusalamūlaṃ.

dn33:1.10.7.pli: alobho kusalamūlaṃ, adoso kusalamūlaṃ, amoho kusalamūlaṃ.

dn33:1.10.35.eng: for sensual pleasures, for existence, and for nonexistence.

dn33:1.10.41.eng: substantialist view, doubt, and misapprehension of precepts and observances.

dn33:1.10.43.eng: sensuality, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

dn33:1.10.47.eng: for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.

dn33:1.10.49.pli: seyyohamasmīti vidhā, sadisohamasmīti vidhā, hīnohamasmīti vidhā.

dn33:1.10.51.pli: atīto addhā, anāgato addhā, paccuppanno addhā.

dn33:1.10.53.pli: sakkāyo anto, sakkāyasamudayo anto, sakkāyanirodho anto.
dn33:1.10.53.eng: substantial reality, the origin of substantial reality, and the cessation of substantial reality.
dn33:1.10.53.comm: At AN 4.33:2.2 cessation is the middle, not an extreme. But SN 22.103 has four extremes.

dn33:1.10.55.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

dn33:1.10.57.eng: the suffering inherent in painful feeling, the suffering inherent in conditions, and the suffering inherent in perishing.

dn33:1.10.59.pli: micchattaniyato rāsi, sammattaniyato rāsi, aniyato rāsi.
dn33:1.10.59.eng: the heap of surety in the wrong way, the heap of surety in the right way, and the heap of lack of surety.
dn33:1.10.59.comm: The “right way” is the eightfold path, the “wrong way” the opposite (SN 45.21). “Surety in the right way” is mentioned often (eg. AN 5.151), although I normally render it “sure path”. “Surety in the wrong way” seems to be found only in later texts. “Lack of surety” is impermanence. And elsewhere these are not said to be “heaps”.

dn33:1.10.61.pli: atītaṃ vā addhānaṃ ārabbha kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, anāgataṃ vā addhānaṃ ārabbha kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, etarahi vā paccuppannaṃ addhānaṃ ārabbha kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
dn33:1.10.61.eng: one is doubtful, uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence about the past, future, and present.
dn33:1.10.61.comm: Despite the explanation, and the prevalence of reading kaṅkhā, the commentary requires the Mahāsaṅgīti reading tama.

dn33:1.10.62.eng: Three things a Realized One need not hide:

dn33:1.10.63.pli: parisuddhakāyasamācāro āvuso tathāgato, natthi tathāgatassa kāyaduccaritaṃ, yaṃ tathāgato rakkheyya:
dn33:1.10.63.eng: The Realized One’s behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is pure. He has no misconduct in these three ways that need be hidden, thinking:

dn33:1.10.64.eng: ‘Don’t let others find this out about me!’

dn33:1.10.65.pli: Parisuddhavacīsamācāro āvuso, tathāgato, natthi tathāgatassa vacīduccaritaṃ, yaṃ tathāgato rakkheyya:

dn33:1.10.67.pli: Parisuddhamanosamācāro, āvuso, tathāgato, natthi tathāgatassa manoduccaritaṃ yaṃ tathāgato rakkheyya:

dn33:1.10.70.pli: rāgo kiñcanaṃ, doso kiñcanaṃ, moho kiñcanaṃ.

dn33:1.10.74.eng: a fire for those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, a fire for householders, and a fire for those worthy of a religious donation.
dn33:1.10.74.comm: AN 7.47:12.3. | For dakkhiṇeyyaggi, compare Sanskrit dakṣiṇāgni, a fire sacrifice for ancestors established in a hearth to the south.

dn33:1.10.76.pli: sanidassanasappaṭighaṃ rūpaṃ, anidassanasappaṭighaṃ rūpaṃ, anidassanaappaṭighaṃ rūpaṃ.
dn33:1.10.76.eng: visible and resistant, invisible and resistant, and invisible and non-resistant.
dn33:1.10.76.comm: Elsewhere found only in Abhidhamma. “Visible and resistant” refers to material phenomena perceivable by the eye. “Invisible and resistant” is a shorthand for material phenomena that are not perceivable by the eye, but which nonetheless impinge on other senses, such as sounds or smells. “Invisible and non-resistant” includes form perceived solely in the mind (Vb 3:49.2).

dn33:1.10.78.eng: good choices, bad choices, and imperturbable choices.

dn33:1.10.80.pli: sekkho puggalo, asekkho puggalo, nevasekkho nāsekkho puggalo.
dn33:1.10.80.eng: a trainee, an adept, and one who is neither a trainee nor an adept.
dn33:1.10.80.comm: The last item is elsewhere found only in Abhidhamma texts. A “trainee” is a noble one who has at least entered the path to stream-entry; an “adept” (asekkha) has completed their training; one who is neither is yet to begin.

dn33:1.10.82.eng: a senior by birth, a senior in the teaching, and a senior by convention.

dn33:1.10.84.pli: dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu.

dn33:1.10.86.eng: what is seen, heard, and suspected.

dn33:1.10.88.pli: santāvuso sattā paccupaṭṭhitakāmā, te paccupaṭṭhitesu kāmesu vasaṃ vattenti, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
dn33:1.10.88.eng: There are sentient beings who desire what is present. They fall under the sway of presently arisen sensual pleasures. Namely, humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

dn33:1.10.89.eng: This is the first kind of sensual rebirth.

dn33:1.10.90.pli: Santāvuso, sattā nimmitakāmā, te nimminitvā nimminitvā kāmesu vasaṃ vattenti, seyyathāpi devā nimmānaratī.
dn33:1.10.90.eng: There are sentient beings who desire to create. Having repeatedly created, they fall under the sway of sensual pleasures. Namely, the gods who love to create.

dn33:1.10.91.eng: This is the second kind of sensual rebirth.

dn33:1.10.92.pli: Santāvuso sattā paranimmitakāmā, te paranimmitesu kāmesu vasaṃ vattenti, seyyathāpi devā paranimmitavasavattī.
dn33:1.10.92.eng: There are sentient beings who desire what is created by others. They fall under the sway of sensual pleasures created by others. Namely, the gods who control what is created by others.

dn33:1.10.93.eng: This is the third kind of sensual rebirth.

dn33:1.10.95.pli: santāvuso sattā uppādetvā uppādetvā sukhaṃ viharanti, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā.
dn33:1.10.95.eng: There are sentient beings who, having repeatedly given rise to it, dwell in pleasure. Namely, the gods of the Divinity’s host.

dn33:1.10.96.eng: This is the first pleasant rebirth.

dn33:1.10.97.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sukhena abhisannā parisannā paripūrā paripphuṭā.
dn33:1.10.97.eng: There are sentient beings who are drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with pleasure.

dn33:1.10.98.eng: Every so often they feel inspired to exclaim:

dn33:1.10.99.pli: ‘aho sukhaṃ, aho sukhan’ti, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
dn33:1.10.99.eng: ‘Oh, what bliss! Oh, what bliss!’ Namely, the gods of streaming radiance.

dn33:1.10.100.eng: This is the second pleasant rebirth.

dn33:1.10.101.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sukhena abhisannā parisannā paripūrā paripphuṭā.
dn33:1.10.101.eng: There are sentient beings who are drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with pleasure.

dn33:1.10.102.pli: Te santaṃyeva tusitā sukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
dn33:1.10.102.eng: Since they’re truly content, they experience pleasure. Namely, the gods of universal beauty.

dn33:1.10.103.eng: This is the third pleasant rebirth.
dn33:1.10.103.comm: The first is unique, the next two from AN 5.170.

dn33:1.10.105.pli: sekkhā paññā, asekkhā paññā, nevasekkhānāsekkhā paññā.
dn33:1.10.105.eng: the wisdom of a trainee, the wisdom of an adept, and the wisdom of one who is neither a trainee nor an adept.

dn33:1.10.107.pli: cintāmayā paññā, sutamayā paññā, bhāvanāmayā paññā.
dn33:1.10.107.eng: wisdom produced by thought, learning, and meditation.
dn33:1.10.107.comm: Otherwise found only in Abhidhamma and other late texts.

dn33:1.10.109.comm: The “weapon of learning” is at AN 7.67:17.3, the “weapon of wisdom” in verse at Dhp 40:3 and Thag 16.3:17.3.

dn33:1.10.111.eng: the faculty of understanding that one’s enlightenment is imminent, the faculty of enlightenment, and the faculty of one who is enlightened.
dn33:1.10.111.comm: Found at SN 48.23:1.3 and Iti 62:2.3, this went on to become a standard Abhidhamma set.

dn33:1.10.113.eng: the eye of the flesh, the eye of clairvoyance, and the eye of wisdom.

dn33:1.10.115.eng: in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom.

dn33:1.10.117.eng: the development of physical endurance, the development of the mind, and the development of wisdom.

dn33:1.10.121.pli: savitakkasavicāro samādhi, avitakkavicāramatto samādhi, avitakkaavicāro samādhi.
dn33:1.10.121.eng: Immersion with placing the mind and keeping it connected. Immersion without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected. Immersion without placing the mind or keeping it connected.
dn33:1.10.121.comm: This threefold presentation of the process of absorption focuses on vitakka (“placing the mind”) and vicāra (“keeping it connected”), looking closely at how they cease (see also DN 34:1.4.7, MN 128:31.4, SN 43.3:1.2, and AN 8.63:3.1). The standard jhāna formula focuses more on the refinement of feelings, from which perspective the first two stages of immersion here fall under the “rapture and bliss born of seclusion”, while only the third qualifies as “rapture and bliss born of immersion”. Thus Analayo describes the two descriptions' as “complementary perspectives on the same process of deepening concentration” (Comparative Study, vol. ii, pg. 739, note 263).

dn33:1.10.123.pli: suññato samādhi, animitto samādhi, appaṇihito samādhi.

dn33:1.10.125.eng: purity of body, speech, and mind.

dn33:1.10.127.eng: sagacity of body, speech, and mind.

dn33:1.10.129.eng: skill in progress, skill in regress, and skill in means.
dn33:1.10.129.comm: AN 6.79:1.3; explained at Vb 16:259.1. These passages, and Thag 2.19:2.1, are the earliest appearances of the phrase “skill in means” (upāyakosalla) that would become famous in later Buddhism.

dn33:1.10.131.eng: the vanity of health, the vanity of youth, and the vanity of life.

dn33:1.10.132.eng: Three ways of putting something in charge:

dn33:1.10.133.eng: putting oneself, the world, or the teaching in charge.

dn33:1.10.135.pli: atītaṃ vā addhānaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheyya:

dn33:1.10.136.eng: ‘That is how it was in the past.’

dn33:1.10.137.pli: anāgataṃ vā addhānaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheyya:

dn33:1.10.138.eng: ‘That is how it will be in the future.’

dn33:1.10.139.pli: etarahi vā paccuppannaṃ addhānaṃ ārabbha kathaṃ katheyya:
dn33:1.10.139.eng: Or you might discuss the present:

dn33:1.10.140.eng: ‘This is how it is at present.’

dn33:1.10.142.pli: pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṃ vijjā, sattānaṃ cutūpapāteñāṇaṃ vijjā, āsavānaṃ khayeñāṇaṃ vijjā.
dn33:1.10.142.eng: recollection of past lives, knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings, and knowledge of the ending of defilements.

dn33:1.10.144.pli: dibbo vihāro, brahmā vihāro, ariyo vihāro.
dn33:1.10.144.eng: the heavenly meditation, the divine meditation, and the noble meditation.
dn33:1.10.144.comm: Called “high and luxurious beds” at AN 3.63:5.3.

dn33:1.10.146.eng: The demonstration of psychic power, the demonstration of revealing, and the demonstration of instruction.

dn33:1.10.147.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tayo dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:1.10.147.eng: These are the teachings grouped by three that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:1.10.148.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.10.148.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:1.11.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:1.11.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by four that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:1.11.2.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ, na vivaditabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.11.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:1.11.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by four?

dn33:1.11.5.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn33:1.11.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn33:1.11.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

dn33:1.11.8.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn33:1.11.8.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn33:1.11.10.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
dn33:1.11.10.eng: A mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

dn33:1.11.11.pli: Uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
dn33:1.11.11.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

dn33:1.11.12.pli: Anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
dn33:1.11.12.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

dn33:1.11.13.pli: Uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
dn33:1.11.13.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

dn33:1.11.15.eng: A mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

dn33:1.11.16.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.

dn33:1.11.17.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.

dn33:1.11.18.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.

dn33:1.11.20.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.20.eng: A mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn33:1.11.21.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.21.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn33:1.11.22.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.22.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

dn33:1.11.23.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.23.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dn33:1.11.25.pli: Atthāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.25.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in this life.

dn33:1.11.26.pli: Atthāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ñāṇadassanapaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.26.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision.

dn33:1.11.27.pli: Atthāvuso samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.27.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness.

dn33:1.11.28.pli: Atthāvuso samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.28.eng: There is a way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements.

dn33:1.11.29.pli: Katamā cāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya saṃvattati?
dn33:1.11.29.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in this life?

dn33:1.11.30.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ …
dn33:1.11.30.eng: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …

dn33:1.11.33.pli: Ayaṃ, āvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.33.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to blissful meditation in this life.

dn33:1.11.34.pli: Katamā cāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ñāṇadassanapaṭilābhāya saṃvattati?
dn33:1.11.34.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision?

dn33:1.11.35.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu ālokasaññaṃ manasi karoti, divāsaññaṃ adhiṭṭhāti yathā divā tathā rattiṃ, yathā rattiṃ tathā divā.
dn33:1.11.35.eng: A mendicant applies their mind to the perception of light, focusing on the perception of day regardless of whether it’s night or day.

dn33:1.11.36.pli: Iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
dn33:1.11.36.eng: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, they develop a mind that’s full of radiance.

dn33:1.11.37.pli: Ayaṃ, āvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā ñāṇadassanapaṭilābhāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.37.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to gaining knowledge and vision.

dn33:1.11.38.pli: Katamā cāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṃvattati?
dn33:1.11.38.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness?

dn33:1.11.39.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno viditā vedanā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
dn33:1.11.39.eng: A mendicant knows feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

dn33:1.11.40.pli: Viditā saññā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
dn33:1.11.40.eng: They know perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

dn33:1.11.41.pli: Viditā vitakkā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti.
dn33:1.11.41.eng: They know thoughts as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

dn33:1.11.42.pli: Ayaṃ, āvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satisampajaññāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.42.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to mindfulness and awareness.

dn33:1.11.43.pli: Katamā cāvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati?
dn33:1.11.43.eng: And what is the way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements?

dn33:1.11.44.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassī viharati.
dn33:1.11.44.eng: A mendicant meditates observing rise and fall in the five grasping aggregates.

dn33:1.11.45.pli: Iti rūpaṃ, iti rūpassa samudayo, iti rūpassa atthaṅgamo.
dn33:1.11.45.eng: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.

dn33:1.11.49.pli: iti viññāṇaṃ, iti viññāṇassa samudayo, iti viññāṇassa atthaṅgamo.
dn33:1.11.49.eng: consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’

dn33:1.11.50.pli: Ayaṃ, āvuso, samādhibhāvanā bhāvitā bahulīkatā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.50.eng: This is the way of developing immersion further that leads to the ending of defilements.

dn33:1.11.52.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṃ. Tathā tatiyaṃ. Tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
dn33:1.11.52.eng: A mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

dn33:1.11.53.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …

dn33:1.11.55.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati. Tathā dutiyaṃ. Tathā tatiyaṃ. Tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
dn33:1.11.55.eng: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
dn33:1.11.55.comm: These are described as “limitless” in the formula, but this is the only early text they are called the “four limitless states” (or “immeasurables”). This is a sign of systematization.

dn33:1.11.57.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.57.eng: A mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

dn33:1.11.58.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.58.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn33:1.11.59.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.59.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

dn33:1.11.60.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:1.11.60.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
dn33:1.11.60.comm: Often described as “formless”, here is the only place we find “four formless states” (āruppā).

dn33:1.11.62.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodeti.
dn33:1.11.62.eng: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.

dn33:1.11.64.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca cīvarahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca cīvaraṃ na paritassati, laddhā ca cīvaraṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati; tāya ca pana itarītaracīvarasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṃseti na paraṃ vambheti.
dn33:1.11.64.eng: A mendicant is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment. They don’t employ improper solicitation for the sake of a robe. They don’t worry if they don’t get a robe. And if they do get a robe, they use it untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape. And on account of that they don’t glorify themselves or put others down.

dn33:1.11.65.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato, ayaṃ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito’.
dn33:1.11.65.eng: A mendicant who is deft, tireless, aware, and mindful in this is said to stand in the ancient, primordial noble tradition.

dn33:1.11.66.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, itarītarapiṇḍapātasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca piṇḍapātahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ na paritassati, laddhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati; tāya ca pana itarītarapiṇḍapātasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṃseti na paraṃ vambheti.
dn33:1.11.66.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of almsfood …

dn33:1.11.67.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato, ayaṃ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito’.

dn33:1.11.68.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, itarītarasenāsanasantuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, na ca senāsanahetu anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ āpajjati; aladdhā ca senāsanaṃ na paritassati, laddhā ca senāsanaṃ agadhito amucchito anajjhāpanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati; tāya ca pana itarītarasenāsanasantuṭṭhiyā nevattānukkaṃseti na paraṃ vambheti.
dn33:1.11.68.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of lodgings …

dn33:1.11.69.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato, ayaṃ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito’.

dn33:1.11.70.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu pahānārāmo hoti pahānarato, bhāvanārāmo hoti bhāvanārato; tāya ca pana pahānārāmatāya pahānaratiyā bhāvanārāmatāya bhāvanāratiyā nevattānukkaṃseti na paraṃ vambheti.
dn33:1.11.70.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant enjoys giving up and loves to give up. They enjoy meditation and love to meditate. But they don’t glorify themselves or put down others on account of their love for giving up and meditation.

dn33:1.11.71.pli: Yo hi tattha dakkho analaso sampajāno paṭissato ayaṃ vuccatāvuso: ‘bhikkhu porāṇe aggaññe ariyavaṃse ṭhito’.
dn33:1.11.71.eng: A mendicant who is deft, tireless, aware, and mindful in this is said to stand in the ancient, primordial noble tradition.
dn33:1.11.71.comm: AN 4.28. The sequence of pahāna (“giving up”) and bhāvanā (“meditation”) is swapped as compared with AN 4.28:4.1.

dn33:1.11.73.eng: The efforts to restrain, to give up, to develop, and to preserve.

dn33:1.11.74.eng: And what is the effort to restrain?

dn33:1.11.75.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
dn33:1.11.75.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

dn33:1.11.76.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
dn33:1.11.76.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

dn33:1.11.77.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

dn33:1.11.78.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

dn33:1.11.79.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

dn33:1.11.80.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

dn33:1.11.81.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
dn33:1.11.81.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

dn33:1.11.82.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ, tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
dn33:1.11.82.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

dn33:1.11.83.eng: This is called the effort to restrain.

dn33:1.11.84.eng: And what is the effort to give up?

dn33:1.11.85.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantiṃ karoti anabhāvaṃ gameti;
dn33:1.11.85.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual,

dn33:1.11.87.eng: or cruel thought that’s arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, eliminates it, and obliterates it.

dn33:1.11.88.pli: uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantiṃ karoti anabhāvaṃ gameti.
dn33:1.11.88.eng: They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

dn33:1.11.89.eng: This is called the effort to give up.

dn33:1.11.90.eng: And what is the effort to develop?

dn33:1.11.91.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ,
dn33:1.11.91.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,

dn33:1.11.97.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
dn33:1.11.97.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

dn33:1.11.98.eng: This is called the effort to develop.

dn33:1.11.99.eng: And what is the effort to preserve?

dn33:1.11.100.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu uppannaṃ bhadrakaṃ samādhinimittaṃ anurakkhati—aṭṭhikasaññaṃ, puḷuvakasaññaṃ, vinīlakasaññaṃ, vicchiddakasaññaṃ, uddhumātakasaññaṃ.
dn33:1.11.100.eng: It’s when a mendicant preserves a meditation subject that’s a fine basis of immersion: the perception of a skeleton, a worm-infested corpse, a livid corpse, a split open corpse, or a bloated corpse.

dn33:1.11.101.eng: This is called the effort to preserve.

dn33:1.11.103.pli: dhamme ñāṇaṃ, anvaye ñāṇaṃ, pariye ñāṇaṃ, sammutiyā ñāṇaṃ.
dn33:1.11.103.eng: knowledge of the teaching, inferential knowledge, knowledge of encompassing, and conventional knowledge.
dn33:1.11.103.comm: “Knowledge of the teaching” is the understanding of the observable principles of the teaching. | “Inferential knowledge” applies that to the past and future, especially in understanding the minds and behaviors of others without reading their minds. | “Knowledge of encompassing” is the psychic ability to read or “encompass” the mind of another. | “Conventional knowledge” is explained as understanding that is not included in the former three (Vb 16:310.1). It would especially include Vinaya matters that are agreed on “by convention” (AN 8.90:1.2, DN 33:1.10.82). | The first two are found at SN 12.33:14.2; see notes there for further discussion. The four are found at DN 34:1.5.3 and Vb 16:307.1.

dn33:1.11.105.pli: dukkhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ.
dn33:1.11.105.eng: knowing about suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

dn33:1.11.107.eng: associating with true persons, listening to the true teaching, rational application of mind, and practicing in line with the teaching.

dn33:1.11.109.pli: Idhāvuso, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti:
dn33:1.11.109.eng: A noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha:

dn33:1.11.110.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho, bhagavā’ti.
dn33:1.11.110.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

dn33:1.11.111.eng: They have experiential confidence in the teaching:

dn33:1.11.112.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
dn33:1.11.112.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

dn33:1.11.113.eng: They have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:

dn33:1.11.114.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā, esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
dn33:1.11.114.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

dn33:1.11.115.pli: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi acchiddehi asabalehi akammāsehi bhujissehi viññuppasatthehi aparāmaṭṭhehi samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
dn33:1.11.115.eng: And a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
dn33:1.11.115.comm: This discourse distinguishes the “factors of a stream-enterer” (sotāpannassa aṅgāni) from the “factors of stream-entry” (sotāpattiyaṅgāni), but elsewhere only the latter term is used SN 12.42:3.1, AN 9.28:4.1.

dn33:1.11.121.pli: kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā tatiyā, viññāṇaṃ catutthaṃ.
dn33:1.11.121.eng: edible food, whether solid or subtle; contact is the second, mental intention the third, and consciousness the fourth.

dn33:1.11.123.pli: Rūpūpāyaṃ vā, āvuso, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭhati rūpārammaṇaṃ rūpappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjati;
dn33:1.11.123.eng: As long as consciousness continues, it gets involved with form, supported by form, established on form. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it grows, increases, and matures.

dn33:1.11.124.eng: Or consciousness gets involved with feeling …

dn33:1.11.125.eng: Or consciousness gets involved with perception …

dn33:1.11.126.pli: saṅkhārūpāyaṃ vā, āvuso, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭhati saṅkhārārammaṇaṃ saṅkhārappatiṭṭhaṃ nandūpasecanaṃ vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjati.
dn33:1.11.126.eng: Or as long as consciousness continues, it gets involved with choices, supported by choices, established on choices. And with a sprinkle of relishing, it grows, increases, and matures.

dn33:1.11.128.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
dn33:1.11.128.eng: making decisions prejudiced by favoritism, hostility, stupidity, and cowardice.

dn33:1.11.129.eng: Four things that give rise to craving:

dn33:1.11.130.pli: cīvarahetu vā, āvuso, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati;
dn33:1.11.130.eng: Craving arises in a mendicant for the sake of robes,

dn33:1.11.131.pli: piṇḍapātahetu vā, āvuso, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati;

dn33:1.11.132.pli: senāsanahetu vā, āvuso, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati;

dn33:1.11.133.pli: itibhavābhavahetu vā, āvuso, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.
dn33:1.11.133.eng: or rebirth in this or that state.

dn33:1.11.135.pli: dukkhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā dandhābhiññā, sukhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā.
dn33:1.11.135.eng: painful practice with slow insight, painful practice with swift insight, pleasant practice with slow insight, and pleasant practice with swift insight.

dn33:1.11.137.pli: akkhamā paṭipadā, khamā paṭipadā, damā paṭipadā, samā paṭipadā.
dn33:1.11.137.eng: impatient practice, patient practice, taming practice, and calming practice.

dn33:1.11.139.pli: anabhijjhā dhammapadaṃ, abyāpādo dhammapadaṃ, sammāsati dhammapadaṃ, sammāsamādhi dhammapadaṃ.
dn33:1.11.139.eng: contentment, good will, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

dn33:1.11.141.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.

dn33:1.11.142.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.

dn33:1.11.143.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.

dn33:1.11.144.eng: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.

dn33:1.11.150.eng: the foundations of wisdom, truth, generosity, and peace.

dn33:1.11.152.pli: ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyo pañho, paṭipucchābyākaraṇīyo pañho, vibhajjabyākaraṇīyo pañho, ṭhapanīyo pañho.
dn33:1.11.152.eng: There is a question that should be answered categorically. There is a question that should be answered analytically. There is a question that should be answered with a counter-question. There is a question that should be set aside.

dn33:1.11.154.eng: There are deeds that are dark with dark result.

dn33:1.11.155.eng: There are deeds that are bright with bright result.

dn33:1.11.156.eng: There are deeds that are dark and bright with dark and bright result.
dn33:1.11.156.comm: By treating ethical decisions via a tetralemma, the Buddha rejects the “law of the excluded middle” and the consequent belief that acts must be either right or wrong.

dn33:1.11.157.pli: Atthāvuso, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
dn33:1.11.157.eng: There are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

dn33:1.11.159.eng: Past lives are to be realized with recollection.

dn33:1.11.160.eng: The passing away and rebirth of sentient beings is to be realized with vision.

dn33:1.11.161.eng: The eight liberations are to be realized with direct meditative experience.

dn33:1.11.162.eng: The ending of defilements is to be realized with wisdom.
dn33:1.11.162.comm: AN 4.189, but the order there is direct experience, recollection, vision, wisdom.

dn33:1.11.164.eng: the floods of sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

dn33:1.11.166.eng: the yokes of sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.
dn33:1.11.166.comm: This and the next at AN 4.10.

dn33:1.11.168.eng: unyoking from the yokes of sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance.

dn33:1.11.170.pli: abhijjhā kāyagantho, byāpādo kāyagantho, sīlabbataparāmāso kāyagantho, idaṃsaccābhiniveso kāyagantho.
dn33:1.11.170.eng: the personal ties to covetousness, ill will, misapprehension of precepts and observances, and the insistence that this is the only truth.

dn33:1.11.172.eng: grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.

dn33:1.11.174.eng: reproduction for creatures born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.
dn33:1.11.174.comm: MN 12:32.1. The four describe the births of different kinds of nāga (SN 29.1) and phoenix (SN 30.1).

dn33:1.11.176.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco asampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkamati, asampajāno mātukucchismiṃ ṭhāti, asampajāno mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, ayaṃ paṭhamā gabbhāvakkanti.
dn33:1.11.176.eng: Someone is unaware when conceived in their mother’s womb, unaware as they remain there, and unaware as they emerge. This is the first kind of conception.

dn33:1.11.177.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, idhekacco sampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkamati, asampajāno mātukucchismiṃ ṭhāti, asampajāno mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, ayaṃ dutiyā gabbhāvakkanti.
dn33:1.11.177.eng: Furthermore, someone is aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, but unaware as they remain there, and unaware as they emerge. This is the second kind of conception.

dn33:1.11.178.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, idhekacco sampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkamati, sampajāno mātukucchismiṃ ṭhāti, asampajāno mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, ayaṃ tatiyā gabbhāvakkanti.
dn33:1.11.178.eng: Furthermore, someone is aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, aware as they remain there, but unaware as they emerge. This is the third kind of conception.

dn33:1.11.179.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, idhekacco sampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkamati, sampajāno mātukucchismiṃ ṭhāti, sampajāno mātukucchimhā nikkhamati, ayaṃ catutthā gabbhāvakkanti.
dn33:1.11.179.eng: Furthermore, someone is aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, aware as they remain there, and aware as they emerge. This is the fourth kind of conception.

dn33:1.11.181.pli: Atthāvuso, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe attasañcetanāyeva kamati, no parasañcetanā.
dn33:1.11.181.eng: There is an incarnation where only one’s own intention is effective, not that of others.

dn33:1.11.182.pli: Atthāvuso, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe parasañcetanāyeva kamati, no attasañcetanā.
dn33:1.11.182.eng: There is an incarnation where only the intention of others is effective, not one’s own.

dn33:1.11.183.pli: Atthāvuso, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe attasañcetanā ceva kamati parasañcetanā ca.
dn33:1.11.183.eng: There is an incarnation where both one’s own and others’ intentions are effective.

dn33:1.11.184.pli: Atthāvuso, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe neva attasañcetanā kamati, no parasañcetanā.
dn33:1.11.184.eng: There is an incarnation where neither one’s own nor others’ intentions are effective.

dn33:1.11.185.eng: Four ways of purifying a religious donation:

dn33:1.11.186.pli: Atthāvuso, dakkhiṇā dāyakato visujjhati no paṭiggāhakato.
dn33:1.11.186.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by the giver, not the recipient.

dn33:1.11.187.pli: Atthāvuso, dakkhiṇā paṭiggāhakato visujjhati no dāyakato.
dn33:1.11.187.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by the recipient, not the giver.

dn33:1.11.188.pli: Atthāvuso, dakkhiṇā neva dāyakato visujjhati no paṭiggāhakato.
dn33:1.11.188.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by neither the giver nor the recipient.

dn33:1.11.189.pli: Atthāvuso, dakkhiṇā dāyakato ceva visujjhati paṭiggāhakato ca.
dn33:1.11.189.eng: There’s a religious donation that’s purified by both the giver and the recipient.

dn33:1.11.191.eng: giving, kindly words, taking care, and equality.

dn33:1.11.193.eng: speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.
dn33:1.11.193.comm: This and the next are found in AN 4.250, etc., but there defined, as below, in terms of speech about what you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known.

dn33:1.11.195.pli: musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī.
dn33:1.11.195.eng: refraining from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

dn33:1.11.197.pli: adiṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, assute sutavāditā, amute mutavāditā, aviññāte viññātavāditā.
dn33:1.11.197.eng: saying you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, but you haven’t.

dn33:1.11.199.pli: adiṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, assute assutavāditā, amute amutavāditā, aviññāte aviññātavāditā.
dn33:1.11.199.eng: saying you haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you haven’t.

dn33:1.11.201.pli: diṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, sute assutavāditā, mute amutavāditā, viññāte aviññātavāditā.
dn33:1.11.201.eng: saying you haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you have.

dn33:1.11.203.pli: diṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, sute sutavāditā, mute mutavāditā, viññāte viññātavāditā.
dn33:1.11.203.eng: saying you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you have.

dn33:1.11.205.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo attantapo hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
dn33:1.11.205.eng: One individual mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.

dn33:1.11.206.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo parantapo hoti paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
dn33:1.11.206.eng: One individual mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.

dn33:1.11.207.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo attantapo ca hoti attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto, parantapo ca paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
dn33:1.11.207.eng: One individual mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

dn33:1.11.208.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo neva attantapo hoti na attaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto na parantapo na paraparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto.
dn33:1.11.208.eng: One individual doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.

dn33:1.11.209.pli: So anattantapo aparantapo diṭṭheva dhamme nicchāto nibbuto sītībhūto sukhappaṭisaṃvedī brahmabhūtena attanā viharati.
dn33:1.11.209.eng: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.
dn33:1.11.209.comm: AN 4.198. | “With self become divine” (brahmabhūtena attanā) deliberately echoes Upaniṣadic language. Pali is sometimes said to lack reference to the cosmic Brahman (in neuter), having only the personal Brahmā (in masculine). The grammatical case of brahma- in the compound here is undetermined, yet no scholar of Sanskrit would hesitate to interpret the common phrase brahmabhūtātmā in the sense “self become one with the cosmic divinity Brahman”. Surely the Pali draws from the same sense, using it to describe Nibbāna.

dn33:1.11.211.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo attahitāya paṭipanno hoti no parahitāya.
dn33:1.11.211.eng: One individual practices to benefit themselves, but not others.

dn33:1.11.212.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo parahitāya paṭipanno hoti no attahitāya.
dn33:1.11.212.eng: One individual practices to benefit others, but not themselves.

dn33:1.11.213.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo neva attahitāya paṭipanno hoti no parahitāya.
dn33:1.11.213.eng: One individual practices to benefit neither themselves nor others.

dn33:1.11.214.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco puggalo attahitāya ceva paṭipanno hoti parahitāya ca.
dn33:1.11.214.eng: One individual practices to benefit both themselves and others.

dn33:1.11.216.pli: tamo tamaparāyano, tamo jotiparāyano, joti tamaparāyano, joti jotiparāyano.
dn33:1.11.216.eng: the dark bound for darkness, the dark bound for light, the light bound for darkness, and the light bound for light.

dn33:1.11.218.eng: the confirmed ascetic, the white lotus ascetic, the pink lotus ascetic, and the delicate ascetic of ascetics.

dn33:1.11.219.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammā sammadakkhātā;
dn33:1.11.219.eng: These are the teachings grouped by four that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:1.11.220.pli: tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:1.11.220.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:1.11.221.eng: The first recitation section is finished.

dn33:2.1.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena pañca dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:2.1.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by five that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:2.1.2.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:2.1.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:2.1.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by five?

dn33:2.1.5.eng: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
dn33:2.1.5.comm: For the distinction between “aggregates” and “grasping aggregates” see SN 22.48, SN 22.82, MN 109.

dn33:2.1.7.eng: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

dn33:2.1.9.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasañhitā rajanīyā,
dn33:2.1.9.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

dn33:2.1.13.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasañhitā rajanīyā.
dn33:2.1.13.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

dn33:2.1.15.eng: hell, the animal realm, the ghost realm, humanity, and the gods.
dn33:2.1.15.comm: Also at MN 12:35.3. Later the asura (“demon” or “titan”) realm was added as the sixth. The number and nature of different realms is always somewhat fluid.

dn33:2.1.17.eng: stinginess with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teachings.

dn33:2.1.19.eng: sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

dn33:2.1.21.eng: substantialist view, doubt, misapprehension of precepts and observances, sensual desire, and ill will.

dn33:2.1.23.eng: desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

dn33:2.1.25.pli: pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī, musāvādā veramaṇī, surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā veramaṇī.
dn33:2.1.25.eng: refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and consuming beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

dn33:2.1.27.pli: Abhabbo, āvuso, khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṃ jīvitā voropetuṃ. Abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṃ theyyasaṅkhātaṃ ādiyituṃ. Abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṃ dhammaṃ paṭisevituṃ. Abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṃ. Abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṃ kāme paribhuñjituṃ, seyyathāpi pubbe āgārikabhūto.
dn33:2.1.27.eng: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a layperson.

dn33:2.1.29.eng: loss of relatives, wealth, health, ethics, and view.

dn33:2.1.30.pli: Nāvuso, sattā ñātibyasanahetu vā bhogabyasanahetu vā rogabyasanahetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
dn33:2.1.30.eng: It is not because of loss of relatives, wealth, or health that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

dn33:2.1.31.pli: Sīlabyasanahetu vā, āvuso, sattā diṭṭhibyasanahetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
dn33:2.1.31.eng: It is because of loss of ethics or view that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
dn33:2.1.31.comm: This and the next at AN 5.130.

dn33:2.1.33.eng: endowment with relatives, wealth, health, ethics, and view.

dn33:2.1.34.pli: Nāvuso, sattā ñātisampadāhetu vā bhogasampadāhetu vā ārogyasampadāhetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
dn33:2.1.34.eng: It is not because of endowment with family, wealth, or health that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn33:2.1.35.pli: Sīlasampadāhetu vā, āvuso, sattā diṭṭhisampadāhetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
dn33:2.1.35.eng: It is because of endowment with ethics or view that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn33:2.1.36.eng: Five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics:

dn33:2.1.37.pli: Idhāvuso, dussīlo sīlavipanno pamādādhikaraṇaṃ mahatiṃ bhogajāniṃ nigacchati,
dn33:2.1.37.eng: Firstly, an unethical person loses great wealth on account of negligence.

dn33:2.1.39.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati,
dn33:2.1.39.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person gets a bad reputation.

dn33:2.1.41.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, dussīlo sīlavipanno yaññadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ, avisārado upasaṅkamati maṅkubhūto,
dn33:2.1.41.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person enters any kind of assembly timid and embarrassed, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

dn33:2.1.43.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, dussīlo sīlavipanno sammūḷho kālaṃ karoti,
dn33:2.1.43.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person feels lost when they die.

dn33:2.1.45.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, dussīlo sīlavipanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati,
dn33:2.1.45.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

dn33:2.1.46.comm: Also at AN 5.213, Ud 8.6:4.1, DN 16:1.23.2, and Kd 6:28.4.1.

dn33:2.1.47.eng: Five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics:

dn33:2.1.48.pli: Idhāvuso, sīlavā sīlasampanno appamādādhikaraṇaṃ mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati,
dn33:2.1.48.eng: Firstly, an ethical person gains great wealth on account of diligence.

dn33:2.1.50.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, sīlavato sīlasampannassa kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchati,
dn33:2.1.50.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person gets a good reputation.

dn33:2.1.52.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, sīlavā sīlasampanno yaññadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ, visārado upasaṅkamati amaṅkubhūto,
dn33:2.1.52.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person enters any kind of assembly bold and self-assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

dn33:2.1.54.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, sīlavā sīlasampanno asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti,
dn33:2.1.54.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person dies not feeling lost.

dn33:2.1.56.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, sīlavā sīlasampanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati,
dn33:2.1.56.eng: Furthermore, when an ethical person’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn33:2.1.58.pli: Codakena, āvuso, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā paro codetabbo.
dn33:2.1.58.eng: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should first establish five things in themselves:

dn33:2.1.59.eng: I will speak at the right time, not at the wrong time.

dn33:2.1.60.eng: I will speak truthfully, not falsely.

dn33:2.1.61.eng: I will speak gently, not harshly.

dn33:2.1.62.eng: I will speak beneficially, not harmfully.

dn33:2.1.63.eng: I will speak lovingly, not from secret hate.

dn33:2.1.64.pli: Codakena, āvuso, bhikkhunā paraṃ codetukāmena ime pañca dhamme ajjhattaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā paro codetabbo.
dn33:2.1.64.eng: A mendicant who wants to accuse another should first establish these five things in themselves.

dn33:2.1.66.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
dn33:2.1.66.eng: A mendicant has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

dn33:2.1.67.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato, lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
dn33:2.1.67.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

dn33:2.1.68.pli: Appābādho hoti appātaṅko, samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya.
dn33:2.1.68.eng: They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.

dn33:2.1.69.pli: Asaṭho hoti amāyāvī, yathābhūtaṃ attānaṃ āvikattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu.
dn33:2.1.69.eng: They’re not devious or deceitful. They reveal themselves honestly to the Teacher or sensible spiritual companions.

dn33:2.1.70.pli: Āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
dn33:2.1.70.eng: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

dn33:2.1.71.pli: Paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
dn33:2.1.71.eng: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

dn33:2.1.73.eng: Aviha, Atappa, the gods fair to see, the fair seeing gods, and Akaniṭṭha.

dn33:2.1.75.eng: one who is extinguished between one life and the next, one who is extinguished upon landing, one who is extinguished without extra effort, one who is extinguished with extra effort, and one who heads upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

dn33:2.1.77.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
dn33:2.1.77.eng: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.

dn33:2.1.78.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ paṭhamo cetokhilo.
dn33:2.1.78.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. This is the first kind of hard-heartedness.

dn33:2.1.79.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati vicikicchati …pe…
dn33:2.1.79.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …

dn33:2.1.82.pli: sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto.
dn33:2.1.82.eng: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.

dn33:2.1.83.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya, ayaṃ pañcamo cetokhilo.
dn33:2.1.83.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving. This is the fifth kind of hard-heartedness.
dn33:2.1.83.comm: AN 5.205; with the next, AN 10.14:1.1, MN 16.

dn33:2.1.85.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho.
dn33:2.1.85.eng: Firstly, a mendicant isn’t free of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for sensual pleasures.

dn33:2.1.86.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu kāmesu avītarāgo hoti avigatacchando avigatapemo avigatapipāso avigatapariḷāho avigatataṇho, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.

dn33:2.1.87.pli: Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
dn33:2.1.87.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

dn33:2.1.88.eng: This is the first shackle of the heart.

dn33:2.1.89.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu kāye avītarāgo hoti …pe…
dn33:2.1.89.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t free of greed for the body …

dn33:2.1.90.eng: They’re not free of greed for form …

dn33:2.1.91.pli: puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehakaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati …pe…
dn33:2.1.91.eng: They eat as much as they like until their bellies are full, then indulge in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing …

dn33:2.1.92.pli: puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti.
dn33:2.1.92.eng: They lead the spiritual life hoping to be reborn in one of the orders of gods, thinking: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’

dn33:2.1.93.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya brahmacariyaṃ carati: ‘imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā devo vā bhavissāmi devaññataro vā’ti, tassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya. Yassa cittaṃ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
dn33:2.1.93.eng: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.

dn33:2.1.94.eng: This is the fifth shackle of the heart.

dn33:2.1.96.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.

dn33:2.1.98.eng: pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.

dn33:2.1.100.eng: faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

dn33:2.1.102.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāme manasikaroto kāmesu cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.102.eng: Take a case where a mendicant focuses on sensual pleasures, but on that their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

dn33:2.1.103.pli: Nekkhammaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto nekkhamme cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.103.eng: But when they focus on renunciation, on that their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

dn33:2.1.104.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ kāmehi.
dn33:2.1.104.eng: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from sensual pleasures.

dn33:2.1.105.pli: Ye ca kāmapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi, na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn33:2.1.105.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of sensual pleasures, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn33:2.1.106.eng: This is how the escape from sensual pleasures is explained.

dn33:2.1.107.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno byāpādaṃ manasikaroto byāpāde cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.107.eng: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on ill will, but their mind does not leap forth …

dn33:2.1.108.pli: Abyāpādaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto abyāpāde cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.108.eng: But when they focus on good will, their mind leaps forth …
