dn33:2.1.109.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ byāpādena.
dn33:2.1.109.eng: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from ill will.

dn33:2.1.110.pli: Ye ca byāpādapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi, na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn33:2.1.110.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of ill will, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn33:2.1.111.eng: This is how the escape from ill will is explained.

dn33:2.1.112.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno vihesaṃ manasikaroto vihesāya cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.112.eng: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on harming, but their mind does not leap forth …

dn33:2.1.113.pli: Avihesaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto avihesāya cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.113.eng: But when they focus on compassion, their mind leaps forth …

dn33:2.1.114.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ vihesāya.
dn33:2.1.114.eng: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from harming.

dn33:2.1.115.pli: Ye ca vihesāpaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi, na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn33:2.1.115.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of harming, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn33:2.1.116.eng: This is how the escape from harming is explained.

dn33:2.1.117.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno rūpe manasikaroto rūpesu cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.117.eng: Take another case where a mendicant focuses on form, but their mind does not leap forth …

dn33:2.1.118.pli: Arūpaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto arūpe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.118.eng: But when they focus on the formless, their mind leaps forth …

dn33:2.1.119.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ rūpehi.
dn33:2.1.119.eng: Their mind is in a good state … well detached from forms.

dn33:2.1.120.pli: Ye ca rūpapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi, na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn33:2.1.120.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of form, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn33:2.1.121.eng: This is how the escape from forms is explained.

dn33:2.1.122.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno sakkāyaṃ manasikaroto sakkāye cittaṃ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.122.eng: Take a case where a mendicant focuses on substantial reality, but their mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided.

dn33:2.1.123.pli: Sakkāyanirodhaṃ kho panassa manasikaroto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṃ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
dn33:2.1.123.eng: But when they focus on the cessation of substantial reality, their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.

dn33:2.1.124.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ sugataṃ subhāvitaṃ suvuṭṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ sakkāyena.
dn33:2.1.124.eng: Their mind is in a good state, well developed, well risen, well freed, and well detached from substantial reality.

dn33:2.1.125.pli: Ye ca sakkāyapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi, na so taṃ vedanaṃ vedeti.
dn33:2.1.125.eng: They’re freed from the distressing and feverish defilements that arise because of substantial reality, so they don’t experience that kind of feeling.

dn33:2.1.126.eng: This is how the escape from substantial reality is explained.

dn33:2.1.128.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī.
dn33:2.1.128.eng: Firstly, the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant.

dn33:2.1.129.pli: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthapaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
dn33:2.1.129.eng: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how the Teacher or a respected spiritual companion teaches it.

dn33:2.1.130.pli: Tassa atthapaṭisaṃvedino dhammapaṭisaṃvedino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
dn33:2.1.130.eng: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

dn33:2.1.131.eng: This is the first opportunity for freedom.

dn33:2.1.132.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena paresaṃ deseti …pe…
dn33:2.1.132.eng: Furthermore, it may be that neither the Teacher nor a respected spiritual companion teaches Dhamma to a mendicant. But the mendicant teaches Dhamma in detail to others as they learned and memorized it. …

dn33:2.1.133.pli: api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ karoti …pe…
dn33:2.1.133.eng: Or the mendicant rehearses the teaching in detail as they learned and memorized it. …

dn33:2.1.134.pli: api ca kho yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati …pe…
dn33:2.1.134.eng: Or the mendicant thinks about and considers the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it. …

dn33:2.1.135.pli: api ca khvassa aññataraṃ samādhinimittaṃ suggahitaṃ hoti sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya.
dn33:2.1.135.eng: Or a meditation subject as a basis of immersion is properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom.

dn33:2.1.136.pli: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno aññataraṃ samādhinimittaṃ suggahitaṃ hoti sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya tathā tathā so tasmiṃ dhamme atthapaṭisaṃvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṃvedī ca.
dn33:2.1.136.eng: That mendicant feels inspired by the meaning and the teaching in that Dhamma, no matter how a meditation subject as a basis of immersion is properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom.

dn33:2.1.137.pli: Tassa atthapaṭisaṃvedino dhammapaṭisaṃvedino pāmojjaṃ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedeti, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
dn33:2.1.137.eng: Feeling inspired, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.

dn33:2.1.138.eng: This is the fifth opportunity for freedom.

dn33:2.1.140.pli: aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā.
dn33:2.1.140.eng: the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in impermanence, the perception of not-self in suffering, the perception of giving up, and the perception of fading away.
dn33:2.1.140.comm: These five are found at AN 5.72 and AN 5.305, and also as part of longer lists. They are not, however, called “perceptions that ripen in freedom”.

dn33:2.1.141.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena pañca dhammā sammadakkhātā;
dn33:2.1.141.eng: These are the teachings grouped by five that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:2.1.142.pli: tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:2.1.142.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:2.2.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cha dhammā sammadakkhātā;
dn33:2.2.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by six that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:2.2.2.pli: tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:2.2.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:2.2.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by six?

dn33:2.2.5.pli: cakkhāyatanaṃ, sotāyatanaṃ, ghānāyatanaṃ, jivhāyatanaṃ, kāyāyatanaṃ, manāyatanaṃ.
dn33:2.2.5.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

dn33:2.2.7.pli: rūpāyatanaṃ, saddāyatanaṃ, gandhāyatanaṃ, rasāyatanaṃ, phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ, dhammāyatanaṃ.
dn33:2.2.7.eng: sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

dn33:2.2.9.pli: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, sotaviññāṇaṃ, ghānaviññāṇaṃ, jivhāviññāṇaṃ, kāyaviññāṇaṃ, manoviññāṇaṃ.
dn33:2.2.9.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousness.

dn33:2.2.11.pli: cakkhusamphasso, sotasamphasso, ghānasamphasso, jivhāsamphasso, kāyasamphasso, manosamphasso.
dn33:2.2.11.eng: contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

dn33:2.2.13.pli: cakkhusamphassajā vedanā, sotasamphassajā vedanā, ghānasamphassajā vedanā, jivhāsamphassajā vedanā, kāyasamphassajā vedanā, manosamphassajā vedanā.
dn33:2.2.13.eng: feeling born of contact through the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

dn33:2.2.15.pli: rūpasaññā, saddasaññā, gandhasaññā, rasasaññā, phoṭṭhabbasaññā, dhammasaññā.
dn33:2.2.15.eng: perceptions of sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

dn33:2.2.17.pli: rūpasañcetanā, saddasañcetanā, gandhasañcetanā, rasasañcetanā, phoṭṭhabbasañcetanā, dhammasañcetanā.
dn33:2.2.17.eng: intention regarding sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

dn33:2.2.19.pli: rūpataṇhā, saddataṇhā, gandhataṇhā, rasataṇhā, phoṭṭhabbataṇhā, dhammataṇhā.
dn33:2.2.19.eng: craving for sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.

dn33:2.2.21.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso; dhamme agāravo viharati appatisso; saṅghe agāravo viharati appatisso; sikkhāya agāravo viharati appatisso; appamāde agāravo viharati appatisso; paṭisanthāre agāravo viharati appatisso.
dn33:2.2.21.eng: A mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.
dn33:2.2.21.comm: As “roots of arguments” at AN 6.36:1.5 and MN 104:6.5 (see below), and as impossibilities for a stream-enterer at AN 6.92.

dn33:2.2.23.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari sagāravo viharati sappatisso; dhamme sagāravo viharati sappatisso; saṅghe sagāravo viharati sappatisso; sikkhāya sagāravo viharati sappatisso; appamāde sagāravo viharati sappatisso; paṭisanthāre sagāravo viharati sappatisso.
dn33:2.2.23.eng: A mendicant has respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, the training, diligence, and hospitality.
dn33:2.2.23.comm: As a cause for the long lasting of the dispensation at AN 6.40:2.2.

dn33:2.2.25.pli: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati;
dn33:2.2.25.eng: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness.

dn33:2.2.26.eng: Hearing a sound with the ear …

dn33:2.2.27.eng: Smelling an odor with the nose …

dn33:2.2.28.eng: Tasting a flavor with the tongue …

dn33:2.2.29.eng: Feeling a touch with the body …

dn33:2.2.30.pli: Manasā dhammaṃ viññāya somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati.
dn33:2.2.30.eng: Knowing an idea with the mind, one is preoccupied with an idea that’s a basis for happiness.
dn33:2.2.30.comm: At AN 3.61:12.1 and MN 140:10.1 these three sets of six are combined as the “eighteen mental preoccupations”.

dn33:2.2.32.pli: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā domanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati …pe…
dn33:2.2.32.eng: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for sadness. …

dn33:2.2.33.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya domanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati.
dn33:2.2.33.eng: Knowing an idea with the mind, one is preoccupied with an idea that’s a basis for sadness.

dn33:2.2.35.pli: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati …pe…
dn33:2.2.35.eng: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for equanimity. …

dn33:2.2.36.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati.
dn33:2.2.36.eng: Knowing an idea with the mind, one is preoccupied with an idea that’s a basis for equanimity.

dn33:2.2.38.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
dn33:2.2.38.eng: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.

dn33:2.2.39.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn33:2.2.39.eng: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

dn33:2.2.40.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
dn33:2.2.40.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness, both in public and in private.

dn33:2.2.41.eng: This too is a warm-hearted quality.

dn33:2.2.42.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
dn33:2.2.42.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness, both in public and in private.

dn33:2.2.43.eng: This too is a warm-hearted quality.

dn33:2.2.44.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi, tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī.
dn33:2.2.44.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.

dn33:2.2.45.eng: This too is a warm-hearted quality.

dn33:2.2.46.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni, tathārūpesu sīlesu sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
dn33:2.2.46.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

dn33:2.2.47.eng: This too is a warm-hearted quality.

dn33:2.2.48.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāyaṃ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
dn33:2.2.48.eng: They live according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and brings one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.

dn33:2.2.49.pli: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṃvattati.
dn33:2.2.49.eng: This warm-hearted quality too makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.

dn33:2.2.51.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is irritable and acrimonious.

dn33:2.2.52.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu kodhano hoti upanāhī, so sattharipi agāravo viharati appatisso, dhammepi agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghepi agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāyapi na paripūrakārī hoti.
dn33:2.2.52.eng: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.

dn33:2.2.53.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghe agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāya na paripūrakārī, so saṅghe vivādaṃ janeti. Yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:2.2.53.eng: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the detriment and suffering of the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.

dn33:2.2.54.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe, āvuso, vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā samanupasseyyātha. Tatra tumhe, āvuso, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānāya vāyameyyātha.
dn33:2.2.54.eng: If you see such a root of dispute in yourselves or others, you should try to give up this bad thing.

dn33:2.2.55.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe, āvuso, vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā na samanupasseyyātha. Tatra tumhe, āvuso, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavāya paṭipajjeyyātha.
dn33:2.2.55.eng: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.

dn33:2.2.56.pli: Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānaṃ hoti. Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavo hoti.
dn33:2.2.56.eng: That’s how to give up this bad root of dispute, so it doesn’t come up in the future.

dn33:2.2.57.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu makkhī hoti paḷāsī …pe…
dn33:2.2.57.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is offensive and contemptuous …

dn33:2.2.60.eng: They have corrupt wishes and wrong view …

dn33:2.2.61.eng: They’re attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.

dn33:2.2.62.pli: yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī, so sattharipi agāravo viharati appatisso, dhammepi agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghepi agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāyapi na paripūrakārī hoti.

dn33:2.2.63.pli: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghe agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāya na paripūrakārī, so saṅghe vivādaṃ janeti. Yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṃ.

dn33:2.2.64.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe, āvuso, vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā samanupasseyyātha. Tatra tumhe, āvuso, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānāya vāyameyyātha.
dn33:2.2.64.eng: If you see such a root of dispute in yourselves or others, you should try to give up this bad thing.

dn33:2.2.65.pli: Evarūpañce tumhe, āvuso, vivādamūlaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā na samanupasseyyātha. Tatra tumhe, āvuso, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavāya paṭipajjeyyātha.
dn33:2.2.65.eng: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.

dn33:2.2.66.pli: Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānaṃ hoti. Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṃ anavassavo hoti.
dn33:2.2.66.eng: That’s how to give up this bad root of dispute, so it doesn’t come up in the future.

dn33:2.2.68.pli: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
dn33:2.2.68.eng: earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

dn33:2.2.71.pli: ‘mettā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā,
dn33:2.2.71.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by love. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

dn33:2.2.72.pli: atha ca pana me byāpādo cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn33:2.2.72.eng: Yet somehow ill will still occupies my mind.’

dn33:2.2.73.pli: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo, ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn33:2.2.73.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.

dn33:2.2.74.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, āvuso, anavakāso, yaṃ mettāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya.
dn33:2.2.74.eng: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the heart’s release by love has been developed and properly implemented,

dn33:2.2.75.pli: Atha ca panassa byāpādo cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn33:2.2.75.eng: yet somehow ill will still occupies the mind.

dn33:2.2.76.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, byāpādassa, yadidaṃ mettā cetovimuttī’ti.
dn33:2.2.76.eng: For it is the heart’s release by love that is the escape from ill will.’

dn33:2.2.78.pli: ‘karuṇā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
dn33:2.2.78.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by compassion. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

dn33:2.2.79.pli: Atha ca pana me vihesā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti,
dn33:2.2.79.eng: Yet somehow the thought of harming still occupies my mind.’

dn33:2.2.80.pli: so ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn33:2.2.80.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn33:2.2.81.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, āvuso, anavakāso, yaṃ karuṇāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya,

dn33:2.2.82.pli: atha ca panassa vihesā cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

dn33:2.2.83.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, vihesāya, yadidaṃ karuṇā cetovimuttī’ti.
dn33:2.2.83.eng: For it is the heart’s release by compassion that is the escape from thoughts of harming.’

dn33:2.2.85.pli: ‘muditā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
dn33:2.2.85.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by rejoicing. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

dn33:2.2.86.pli: Atha ca pana me arati cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti,
dn33:2.2.86.eng: Yet somehow discontent still occupies my mind.’

dn33:2.2.87.pli: so ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn33:2.2.87.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn33:2.2.88.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, āvuso, anavakāso, yaṃ muditāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya,

dn33:2.2.89.pli: atha ca panassa arati cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

dn33:2.2.90.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, aratiyā, yadidaṃ muditā cetovimuttī’ti.
dn33:2.2.90.eng: For it is the heart’s release by rejoicing that is the escape from discontent.’

dn33:2.2.92.pli: ‘upekkhā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
dn33:2.2.92.eng: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by equanimity. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

dn33:2.2.93.pli: Atha ca pana me rāgo cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn33:2.2.93.eng: Yet somehow desire still occupies my mind.’

dn33:2.2.94.pli: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn33:2.2.94.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn33:2.2.95.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, āvuso, anavakāso, yaṃ upekkhāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya,

dn33:2.2.96.pli: atha ca panassa rāgo cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

dn33:2.2.97.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, rāgassa, yadidaṃ upekkhā cetovimuttī’ti.
dn33:2.2.97.eng: For it is the heart’s release by equanimity that is the escape from desire.’

dn33:2.2.99.pli: ‘animittā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
dn33:2.2.99.eng: ‘I’ve developed the signless release of the heart. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.

dn33:2.2.100.pli: Atha ca pana me nimittānusāri viññāṇaṃ hotī’ti.
dn33:2.2.100.eng: Yet somehow my consciousness still follows after signs.’

dn33:2.2.101.pli: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn33:2.2.101.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …

dn33:2.2.102.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, āvuso, anavakāso, yaṃ animittāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya,

dn33:2.2.103.pli: atha ca panassa nimittānusāri viññāṇaṃ bhavissati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

dn33:2.2.104.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṃ, yadidaṃ animittā cetovimuttī’ti.
dn33:2.2.104.eng: For it is the signless release of the heart that is the escape from all signs.’

dn33:2.2.106.pli: ‘asmīti kho me vigataṃ, ayamahamasmīti na samanupassāmi,
dn33:2.2.106.eng: ‘I’m rid of the conceit “I am”. And I don’t regard anything as “I am this”.

dn33:2.2.107.pli: atha ca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṃ cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
dn33:2.2.107.eng: Yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupies my mind.’

dn33:2.2.108.pli: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṃ, na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya.
dn33:2.2.108.eng: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.

dn33:2.2.109.pli: Aṭṭhānametaṃ, āvuso, anavakāso, yaṃ asmīti vigate ayamahamasmīti asamanupassato,
dn33:2.2.109.eng: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the conceit “I am” has been done away with, and nothing is regarded as “I am this”,

dn33:2.2.110.pli: atha ca panassa vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṃ cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn33:2.2.110.eng: yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupy the mind.

dn33:2.2.111.pli: Nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallassa, yadidaṃ asmimānasamugghāto’ti.
dn33:2.2.111.eng: For it is the uprooting of the conceit “I am” that is the escape from the dart of doubt and indecision.’

dn33:2.2.113.pli: dassanānuttariyaṃ, savanānuttariyaṃ, lābhānuttariyaṃ, sikkhānuttariyaṃ, pāricariyānuttariyaṃ, anussatānuttariyaṃ.
dn33:2.2.113.eng: the unsurpassable seeing, listening, acquisition, training, service, and recollection.

dn33:2.2.115.pli: buddhānussati, dhammānussati, saṅghānussati, sīlānussati, cāgānussati, devatānussati.
dn33:2.2.115.eng: the recollection of the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, ethics, generosity, and the deities.

dn33:2.2.117.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn33:2.2.117.eng: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn33:2.2.118.eng: Hearing a sound with their ears … Smelling an odor with their nose … Tasting a flavor with their tongue … Feeling a touch with their body …

dn33:2.2.119.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn33:2.2.119.eng: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn33:2.2.121.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco kaṇhābhijātiko samāno kaṇhaṃ dhammaṃ abhijāyati.
dn33:2.2.121.eng: Someone born into a dark class gives rise to a dark result.

dn33:2.2.122.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco kaṇhābhijātiko samāno sukkaṃ dhammaṃ abhijāyati.
dn33:2.2.122.eng: Someone born into a dark class gives rise to a bright result.

dn33:2.2.123.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco kaṇhābhijātiko samāno akaṇhaṃ asukkaṃ nibbānaṃ abhijāyati.
dn33:2.2.123.eng: Someone born into a dark class gives rise to extinguishment, which is neither dark nor bright.

dn33:2.2.124.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco sukkābhijātiko samāno sukkaṃ dhammaṃ abhijāyati.
dn33:2.2.124.eng: Someone born into a bright class gives rise to a bright result.

dn33:2.2.125.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco sukkābhijātiko samāno kaṇhaṃ dhammaṃ abhijāyati.
dn33:2.2.125.eng: Someone born into a bright class gives rise to a dark result.

dn33:2.2.126.pli: Idha panāvuso, ekacco sukkābhijātiko samāno akaṇhaṃ asukkaṃ nibbānaṃ abhijāyati.
dn33:2.2.126.eng: Someone born into a bright class gives rise to extinguishment, which is neither dark nor bright.
dn33:2.2.126.comm: In AN 6.57 this is a response to the doctrine of Pūraṇa Kassapa.

dn33:2.2.128.pli: aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
dn33:2.2.128.eng: the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in impermanence, the perception of not-self in suffering, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation.
dn33:2.2.128.comm: At AN 6.142 and AN 6.35, but not called “perceptions that help penetration”.

dn33:2.2.129.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cha dhammā sammadakkhātā;
dn33:2.2.129.eng: These are the teachings grouped by six that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:2.2.130.pli: tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:2.2.130.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:2.3.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena satta dhammā sammadakkhātā;
dn33:2.3.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by seven that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:2.3.2.pli: tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:2.3.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:2.3.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by seven?

dn33:2.3.5.pli: saddhādhanaṃ, sīladhanaṃ, hiridhanaṃ, ottappadhanaṃ, sutadhanaṃ, cāgadhanaṃ, paññādhanaṃ.
dn33:2.3.5.eng: the riches of faith, ethics, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
dn33:2.3.5.comm: Ariyadhana appears to be constructed after ācariyadhana, “a teacher’s fee”, and hence ariya here would be a noun rather than verb.

dn33:2.3.7.pli: satisambojjhaṅgo, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītisambojjhaṅgo, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, samādhisambojjhaṅgo, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo.
dn33:2.3.7.eng: mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.

dn33:2.3.9.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati.
dn33:2.3.9.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, and right mindfulness.

dn33:2.3.11.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, muṭṭhassati hoti, duppañño hoti.
dn33:2.3.11.eng: a mendicant is faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.

dn33:2.3.13.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, upaṭṭhitassati hoti, paññavā hoti.
dn33:2.3.13.eng: a mendicant is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

dn33:2.3.14.eng: Seven aspects of the teachings of the true persons:

dn33:2.3.15.pli: idhāvuso, bhikkhu dhammaññū ca hoti atthaññū ca attaññū ca mattaññū ca kālaññū ca parisaññū ca puggalaññū ca.
dn33:2.3.15.eng: a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, knows themselves, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows individuals.
dn33:2.3.15.comm: At AN 7.68 dhamma in this context is shown to be “teachings”, not “qualities”.

dn33:2.3.17.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sikkhāsamādāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca sikkhāsamādāne avigatapemo.
dn33:2.3.17.eng: A mendicant has a keen enthusiasm to undertake the training …

dn33:2.3.18.pli: Dhammanisantiyā tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca dhammanisantiyā avigatapemo.

dn33:2.3.19.pli: Icchāvinaye tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca icchāvinaye avigatapemo.

dn33:2.3.20.pli: Paṭisallāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca paṭisallāne avigatapemo.

dn33:2.3.21.pli: Vīriyārambhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca vīriyārambhe avigatapemo.

dn33:2.3.22.pli: Satinepakke tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca satinepakke avigatapemo.

dn33:2.3.23.pli: Diṭṭhipaṭivedhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca diṭṭhipaṭivedhe avigatapemo.
dn33:2.3.23.eng: to penetrate theoretically. And they don’t lose these desires in the future.

dn33:2.3.25.pli: aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
dn33:2.3.25.eng: the perception of impermanence, the perception of not-self, the perception of ugliness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation.
dn33:2.3.25.comm: At AN 7.616, but not called “seven perceptions”.

dn33:2.3.27.pli: saddhābalaṃ, vīriyabalaṃ, hiribalaṃ, ottappabalaṃ, satibalaṃ, samādhibalaṃ, paññābalaṃ.
dn33:2.3.27.eng: faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

dn33:2.3.29.pli: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
dn33:2.3.29.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

dn33:2.3.30.eng: This is the first plane of consciousness.

dn33:2.3.31.pli: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
dn33:2.3.31.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.

dn33:2.3.32.eng: This is the second plane of consciousness.

dn33:2.3.33.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
dn33:2.3.33.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.

dn33:2.3.34.eng: This is the third plane of consciousness.

dn33:2.3.35.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
dn33:2.3.35.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.

dn33:2.3.36.eng: This is the fourth plane of consciousness.

dn33:2.3.37.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
dn33:2.3.37.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.

dn33:2.3.38.eng: This is the fifth plane of consciousness.

dn33:2.3.39.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
dn33:2.3.39.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn33:2.3.40.eng: This is the sixth plane of consciousness.

dn33:2.3.41.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
dn33:2.3.41.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

dn33:2.3.42.eng: This is the seventh plane of consciousness.

dn33:2.3.43.eng: Seven individuals worthy of a religious donation:

dn33:2.3.44.pli: ubhatobhāgavimutto, paññāvimutto, kāyasakkhi, diṭṭhippatto, saddhāvimutto, dhammānusārī, saddhānusārī.
dn33:2.3.44.eng: one freed both ways, one freed by wisdom, a direct witness, one attained to view, one freed by faith, a follower of teachings, and a follower by faith.

dn33:2.3.46.pli: kāmarāgānusayo, paṭighānusayo, diṭṭhānusayo, vicikicchānusayo, mānānusayo, bhavarāgānusayo, avijjānusayo.
dn33:2.3.46.eng: sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

dn33:2.3.48.pli: anunayasaṃyojanaṃ, paṭighasaṃyojanaṃ, diṭṭhisaṃyojanaṃ, vicikicchāsaṃyojanaṃ, mānasaṃyojanaṃ, bhavarāgasaṃyojanaṃ, avijjāsaṃyojanaṃ.
dn33:2.3.48.eng: attraction, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

dn33:2.3.49.pli: Satta adhikaraṇasamathā uppannuppannānaṃ adhikaraṇānaṃ samathāya vūpasamāya—
dn33:2.3.49.eng: Seven principles for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise:

dn33:2.3.50.pli: sammukhāvinayo dātabbo, sativinayo dātabbo, amūḷhavinayo dātabbo, paṭiññāya kāretabbaṃ, yebhuyyasikā, tassapāpiyasikā, tiṇavatthārako.
dn33:2.3.50.eng: Resolution face-to-face to be applied. Resolution through recollection to be granted. Resolution because of past insanity to be granted. Acting according to what has been admitted. Majority decision. Further penalty. Covering over as if with grass.

dn33:3.1.98.pli: Idhāvuso, ekacco dānaṃ deti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
dn33:3.1.98.eng: First, someone gives to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

dn33:3.1.99.eng: Whatever they give they expect back.

dn33:3.1.100.pli: So passati khattiyamahāsālaṃ vā brāhmaṇamahāsālaṃ vā gahapatimahāsālaṃ vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaṃ samaṅgībhūtaṃ paricārayamānaṃ.
dn33:3.1.100.eng: They see an affluent aristocrat or brahmin or householder amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

dn33:3.1.102.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā khattiyamahāsālānaṃ vā brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṃ vā gahapatimahāsālānaṃ vā sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
dn33:3.1.102.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders!’

dn33:3.1.103.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti, tassa taṃ cittaṃ hīne vimuttaṃ uttari abhāvitaṃ tatrūpapattiyā saṃvattati.
dn33:3.1.103.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it. As they’ve settled for less and not developed further, their thought leads to rebirth there.
dn33:3.1.103.comm: “Settled for less” also occurs at AN 8.35:1.9. Readings vary between hīne vimuttaṁ (“released in what is inferior”, per MS) and hīne ’dhimuttaṁ (“resolved upon what is inferior”). This is an example of an ambiguity between vi + √muc (“release”) and adhi + √muc (“resolve”) that is sometimes seen in Pali texts. The subcommentary reads vimuttaṁ and offers two explanations: “‘Released’ (vimuttaṁ) means ‘resolved’ (adhimuttaṁ); the meaning is slants, slopes, and inclines. Or else ‘released’ means ‘set free’ (vissaṭṭhaṁ).” Given that it is clearly accepted in the commentarial tradition, and that it is the more difficult reading, it seems we must accept vimuttaṁ as the correct reading here. But from context, and from the subcommentary, it has the same sense as adhimutta, namely, “resolved upon”. This goes some way to explaining the ambiguity between the two words, as they not only have a similar form, but their meanings can overlap too.

dn33:3.1.133.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
dn33:3.1.133.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the Divinity’s host!’

dn33:3.1.134.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti, tassa taṃ cittaṃ hīne vimuttaṃ uttari abhāvitaṃ tatrūpapattiyā saṃvattati.
dn33:3.1.134.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it. As they’ve settled for less and not developed further, their thought leads to rebirth there.

dn33:3.1.135.pli: Tañca kho sīlavato vadāmi no dussīlassa;
dn33:3.1.135.eng: But I say that this is only for those of ethical conduct, not for the unethical.

dn33:3.1.136.eng: And for those free of desire, not those with desire.
dn33:3.1.136.comm: Previous rebirths required only ethics. Rebirth in the Brahmā realm, however, requires the freedom of the mind from hindrances through practicing absorption.

dn33:3.1.137.eng: The heart’s wish of an ethical person succeeds because of their freedom from desire.

dn33:3.1.139.pli: khattiyaparisā, brāhmaṇaparisā, gahapatiparisā, samaṇaparisā, cātumahārājikaparisā, tāvatiṃsaparisā, māraparisā, brahmaparisā.
dn33:3.1.139.eng: the assemblies of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics. An assembly of the gods of the four great kings. An assembly of the gods of the thirty-three. An assembly of Māras. An assembly of divinities.

dn33:3.1.141.pli: lābho ca, alābho ca, yaso ca, ayaso ca, nindā ca, pasaṃsā ca, sukhañca, dukkhañca.
dn33:3.1.141.eng: gain and loss, fame and disgrace, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.

dn33:3.1.143.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn33:3.1.143.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.144.eng: This is the first dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.145.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti—
dn33:3.1.145.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.147.eng: This is the second dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.148.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn33:3.1.148.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.149.eng: This is the third dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.150.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn33:3.1.150.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly. Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.151.eng: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.152.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni.
dn33:3.1.152.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

dn33:3.1.153.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma umāpupphaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ;
dn33:3.1.153.eng: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

dn33:3.1.154.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn33:3.1.154.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.155.eng: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.156.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni.
dn33:3.1.156.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

dn33:3.1.157.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kaṇikārapupphaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ;
dn33:3.1.157.eng: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

dn33:3.1.158.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn33:3.1.158.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.159.eng: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.160.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni.
dn33:3.1.160.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.

dn33:3.1.161.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma bandhujīvakapupphaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ;
dn33:3.1.161.eng: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.

dn33:3.1.162.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn33:3.1.162.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.163.eng: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.164.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni.
dn33:3.1.164.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.

dn33:3.1.165.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma osadhitārakā odātā odātavaṇṇā odātanidassanā odātanibhāsā, seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ odātaṃ odātavaṇṇaṃ odātanidassanaṃ odātanibhāsaṃ;
dn33:3.1.165.eng: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.

dn33:3.1.166.pli: evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni, ‘tāni abhibhuyya jānāmi passāmī’ti evaṃsaññī hoti.
dn33:3.1.166.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn33:3.1.167.eng: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.

dn33:3.1.169.eng: Having physical form, they see forms.

dn33:3.1.171.eng: Not perceiving physical form internally, they see forms externally.

dn33:3.1.175.pli: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.1.175.eng: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

dn33:3.1.177.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.1.177.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn33:3.1.179.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.1.179.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

dn33:3.1.181.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.1.181.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

dn33:3.1.183.pli: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.1.183.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

dn33:3.1.185.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena aṭṭha dhammā sammadakkhātā;
dn33:3.1.185.eng: These are the teachings grouped by eight that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:3.1.186.pli: tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:3.1.186.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:3.2.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena nava dhammā sammadakkhātā;
dn33:3.2.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by nine that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:3.2.2.pli: tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:3.2.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:3.2.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by nine?

dn33:3.2.5.eng: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me,’ you harbor resentment.

dn33:3.2.6.eng: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me’ …

dn33:3.2.8.pli: ‘piyassa me manāpassa anatthaṃ acarī’ti āghātaṃ bandhati …pe…
dn33:3.2.8.eng: ‘They did wrong by someone I love’ …

dn33:3.2.9.eng: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love’ …

dn33:3.2.10.eng: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love’ …

dn33:3.2.11.pli: ‘appiyassa me amanāpassa atthaṃ acarī’ti āghātaṃ bandhati …pe…

dn33:3.2.13.eng: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike,’ you harbor resentment.

dn33:3.2.14.eng: Nine ways to get rid of resentment:

dn33:3.2.15.pli: ‘Anatthaṃ me acari, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;
dn33:3.2.15.eng: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.

dn33:3.2.16.pli: ‘anatthaṃ me carati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;
dn33:3.2.16.eng: Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me …’ …

dn33:3.2.17.pli: ‘anatthaṃ me carissati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;

dn33:3.2.18.eng: ‘They did wrong by someone I love …’ …

dn33:3.2.19.eng: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love …’ …

dn33:3.2.20.pli: anatthaṃ carissati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti;
dn33:3.2.20.eng: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love …’ …

dn33:3.2.23.pli: atthaṃ carissati, taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṃ paṭivineti.
dn33:3.2.23.eng: Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?’ you get rid of resentment.

dn33:3.2.25.pli: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
dn33:3.2.25.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

dn33:3.2.26.eng: This is the first abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.27.pli: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
dn33:3.2.27.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.

dn33:3.2.28.eng: This is the second abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.29.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
dn33:3.2.29.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.

dn33:3.2.30.eng: This is the third abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.31.pli: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
dn33:3.2.31.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.

dn33:3.2.32.eng: This is the fourth abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.33.pli: Santāvuso, sattā asaññino appaṭisaṃvedino, seyyathāpi devā asaññasattā.
dn33:3.2.33.eng: There are sentient beings that are non-percipient and do not experience anything, such as the gods who are non-percipient beings.

dn33:3.2.34.eng: This is the fifth abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.35.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
dn33:3.2.35.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.

dn33:3.2.36.eng: This is the sixth abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.37.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
dn33:3.2.37.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn33:3.2.38.eng: This is the seventh abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.39.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
dn33:3.2.39.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

dn33:3.2.40.eng: This is the eighth abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.41.pli: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagā.
dn33:3.2.41.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness. They have been reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

dn33:3.2.42.eng: This is the ninth abode of sentient beings.

dn33:3.2.44.pli: Idhāvuso, tathāgato ca loke uppanno hoti arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca desiyati opasamiko parinibbāniko sambodhagāmī sugatappavedito.
dn33:3.2.44.eng: Firstly, a Realized One has arisen in the world. He teaches the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One.

dn33:3.2.45.eng: But that individual has been reborn in hell.

dn33:3.2.46.eng: This is the first lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.47.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, tathāgato ca loke uppanno hoti arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, dhammo ca desiyati opasamiko parinibbāniko sambodhagāmī sugatappavedito.
dn33:3.2.47.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn33:3.2.48.eng: But that individual has been reborn in the animal realm.

dn33:3.2.49.eng: This is the second lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.50.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn33:3.2.51.eng: But an individual has been reborn in the ghost realm.

dn33:3.2.52.eng: This is the third lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.53.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn33:3.2.54.eng: But that individual has been reborn among the titans.

dn33:3.2.55.eng: This is the fourth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.56.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn33:3.2.57.eng: But that individual has been reborn in one of the long-lived orders of gods.

dn33:3.2.58.eng: This is the fifth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.59.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn33:3.2.60.pli: paccantimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti milakkhesu aviññātāresu, yattha natthi gati bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
dn33:3.2.60.eng: But that individual has been reborn in the borderlands, among uneducated foreigners, where monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen do not go.
dn33:3.2.60.comm: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.3.10 warns that, because the knowledge of the gods have not reached them, the lands beyond the borders are the domain of death.

dn33:3.2.61.eng: This is the sixth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.62.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn33:3.2.63.pli: majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti. So ca hoti micchādiṭṭhiko viparītadassano:
dn33:3.2.63.eng: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they have wrong view and distorted perspective:

dn33:3.2.64.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
dn33:3.2.64.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

dn33:3.2.65.eng: This is the seventh lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.66.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One has arisen in the world.

dn33:3.2.67.pli: majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti. So ca hoti duppañño jaḷo eḷamūgo, nappaṭibalo subhāsitadubbhāsitānamatthamaññātuṃ.
dn33:3.2.67.eng: And an individual is reborn in a central country. But they’re witless, dull, idiotic, and unable to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.

dn33:3.2.68.eng: This is the eighth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.

dn33:3.2.69.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, tathāgato ca loke na uppanno hoti arahaṃ sammāsambuddho,
dn33:3.2.69.eng: Furthermore, no Realized One has arisen in the world,

dn33:3.2.70.pli: dhammo ca na desiyati opasamiko parinibbāniko sambodhagāmī sugatappavedito. Ayañca puggalo majjhimesu janapadesu paccājāto hoti, so ca hoti paññavā ajaḷo aneḷamūgo, paṭibalo subhāsitadubbhāsitānamatthamaññātuṃ.
dn33:3.2.70.eng: so there is no teaching of the Dhamma leading to peace, extinguishment, awakening, as proclaimed by the Holy One. But an individual is reborn in a central country. And they’re wise, bright, clever, and able to distinguish what is well said from what is poorly said.

dn33:3.2.71.eng: This is the ninth lost opportunity for spiritual practice.
dn33:3.2.71.comm: Eight at AN 8.29 and DN 34:2.1.122; the ninth here is made by adding the asura rebirth.

dn33:3.2.73.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.73.eng: A mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn33:3.2.74.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.74.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

dn33:3.2.75.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.75.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

dn33:3.2.76.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.76.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dn33:3.2.77.pli: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā …pe… ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.77.eng: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

dn33:3.2.78.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.78.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn33:3.2.79.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.79.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

dn33:3.2.80.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.80.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

dn33:3.2.81.pli: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.2.81.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

dn33:3.2.83.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa kāmasaññā niruddhā hoti.
dn33:3.2.83.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, sensual perceptions have ceased.

dn33:3.2.84.pli: Dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā niruddhā honti.
dn33:3.2.84.eng: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.

dn33:3.2.85.pli: Tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa pīti niruddhā hoti.
dn33:3.2.85.eng: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.

dn33:3.2.86.pli: Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa assāsapassāssā niruddhā honti.
dn33:3.2.86.eng: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.

dn33:3.2.87.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.

dn33:3.2.88.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.

dn33:3.2.89.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.

dn33:3.2.90.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.

dn33:3.2.91.pli: Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca niruddhā honti.
dn33:3.2.91.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
dn33:3.2.91.comm: Also at AN 9.31 and AN 9.61. Compare the “progressive cessation of conditions” at SN 36.11.

dn33:3.2.92.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena nava dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:3.2.92.eng: These are the teachings grouped by nine that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:3.2.93.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:3.2.93.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:3.3.1.pli: Atthi kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dasa dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:3.3.1.eng: There are teachings grouped by ten that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:3.3.2.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ …pe… atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn33:3.3.2.eng: You should all recite these in concert.

dn33:3.3.3.eng: What are the teachings grouped by ten?

dn33:3.3.5.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
dn33:3.3.5.eng: Firstly, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

dn33:3.3.6.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati, ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.

dn33:3.3.7.eng: This is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.8.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthā sabyañjanā kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
dn33:3.3.8.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

dn33:3.3.9.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.

dn33:3.3.10.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.11.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
dn33:3.3.11.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.

dn33:3.3.12.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.

dn33:3.3.13.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.14.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṃ.
dn33:3.3.14.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re patient, and take instruction respectfully.

dn33:3.3.15.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu suvaco hoti …pe… padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṃ.

dn33:3.3.16.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.17.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṃ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni, tattha dakkho hoti analaso tatrupāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgato, alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ.
dn33:3.3.17.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is deft and tireless in a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, understanding how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.

dn33:3.3.18.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṃ …pe… alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ.

dn33:3.3.19.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.20.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro, abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.
dn33:3.3.20.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant loves the teachings and is a delight to converse with, being full of joy in the teaching and training.

dn33:3.3.22.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.23.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarehi cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi.
dn33:3.3.23.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

dn33:3.3.25.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.26.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
dn33:3.3.26.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

dn33:3.3.27.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati …pe… anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.

dn33:3.3.28.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.29.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
dn33:3.3.29.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
dn33:3.3.29.comm: The pre-Buddhist sense of sati is “memory”, while “mindfulness” evolved from the practice of “remembering” scripture, creating an uninterrupted flow state in the present. In this sense, mindfulness can be understood as the element of continuity that knits consciousness together in a coherent stream. Thus when practicing “mindfulness of breathing” one pays continuous attention to the breaths, not “forgetting” what one is doing.

dn33:3.3.30.pli: Yaṃpāvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti …pe… saritā anussaritā.

dn33:3.3.31.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.32.pli: Puna caparaṃ, āvuso, bhikkhu paññavā hoti, udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammādukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
dn33:3.3.32.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

dn33:3.3.34.eng: This too is a quality that serves as protector.

dn33:3.3.36.pli: Pathavīkasiṇameko sañjānāti, uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ advayaṃ appamāṇaṃ.
dn33:3.3.36.eng: Someone perceives the meditation on universal earth above, below, across, undivided and limitless.

dn33:3.3.37.eng: They perceive the meditation on universal water …

dn33:3.3.45.pli: viññāṇakasiṇameko sañjānāti, uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ advayaṃ appamāṇaṃ.
dn33:3.3.45.eng: They perceive the meditation on universal consciousness above, below, across, undivided and limitless.
dn33:3.3.45.comm: AN 10.25. Kaṣina means “universal”, “totality”, and it refers to a measureless state of jhāna. In later usage it became a term for a physical object, such as a disk, on which a meditator focused, but it never has this meaning in early texts. Yājñavalkya says that, just as salt is “entirely” salty, the Self is an “entire mass of consciousness” (kṛtsnaḥ prajñānaghana eva, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.5.13).

dn33:3.3.47.pli: pāṇātipāto, adinnādānaṃ, kāmesumicchācāro, musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo, abhijjhā, byāpādo, micchādiṭṭhi.
dn33:3.3.47.eng: killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.

dn33:3.3.49.pli: pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī, musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī, anabhijjhā, abyāpādo, sammādiṭṭhi.
dn33:3.3.49.eng: refraining from killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; refraining from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.

dn33:3.3.51.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti, chaḷaṅgasamannāgato, ekārakkho, caturāpasseno, paṇunnapaccekasacco, samavayasaṭṭhesano, anāvilasaṅkappo, passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro, suvimuttacitto, suvimuttapañño.
dn33:3.3.51.eng: A mendicant has given up five factors, possesses six factors, has a single guard, has four supports, has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth, has totally given up searching, has unsullied intentions, has stilled the physical process, and is well freed in mind and well freed by wisdom.

dn33:3.3.52.eng: And how has a mendicant given up five factors?

dn33:3.3.53.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmacchando pahīno hoti, byāpādo pahīno hoti, thinamiddhaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti, vicikicchā pahīnā hoti.
dn33:3.3.53.eng: It’s when a mendicant has given up sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

dn33:3.3.54.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu pañcaṅgavippahīno hoti.
dn33:3.3.54.eng: That’s how a mendicant has given up five factors.

dn33:3.3.55.eng: And how does a mendicant possess six factors?

dn33:3.3.56.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn33:3.3.56.eng: A mendicant, seeing a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn33:3.3.57.eng: Hearing a sound with their ears … Smelling an odor with their nose … Tasting a flavor with their tongue … Feeling a touch with their body …

dn33:3.3.58.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
dn33:3.3.58.eng: Knowing an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

dn33:3.3.59.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu chaḷaṅgasamannāgato hoti.
dn33:3.3.59.eng: That’s how a mendicant possesses six factors.

dn33:3.3.60.eng: And how does a mendicant have a single guard?

dn33:3.3.61.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu satārakkhena cetasā samannāgato hoti.
dn33:3.3.61.eng: It’s when a mendicant’s heart is guarded by mindfulness.

dn33:3.3.62.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu ekārakkho hoti.
dn33:3.3.62.eng: That’s how a mendicant has a single guard.

dn33:3.3.63.eng: And how does a mendicant have four supports?

dn33:3.3.64.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodeti.
dn33:3.3.64.eng: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.

dn33:3.3.65.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu caturāpasseno hoti.
dn33:3.3.65.eng: That’s how a mendicant has four supports.

dn33:3.3.66.eng: And how has a mendicant cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth?

dn33:3.3.67.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno yāni tāni puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ puthupaccekasaccāni, sabbāni tāni nunnāni honti paṇunnāni cattāni vantāni muttāni pahīnāni paṭinissaṭṭhāni.
dn33:3.3.67.eng: Different ascetics and brahmins have different idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth. A mendicant has cast out, cast aside, thrown out, discarded, let go of, given up, and relinquished all these.

dn33:3.3.68.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu paṇunnapaccekasacco hoti.
dn33:3.3.68.eng: That’s how a mendicant has cast aside idiosyncratic interpretations of the truth.

dn33:3.3.69.eng: And how has a mendicant totally given up searching?

dn33:3.3.70.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmesanā pahīnā hoti, bhavesanā pahīnā hoti, brahmacariyesanā paṭippassaddhā.
dn33:3.3.70.eng: It’s when they’ve given up searching for sensual pleasures, for continued existence, and for a spiritual path.

dn33:3.3.71.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu samavayasaṭṭhesano hoti.
dn33:3.3.71.eng: That’s how a mendicant has totally given up searching.

dn33:3.3.72.eng: And how does a mendicant have unsullied intentions?

dn33:3.3.73.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāmasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, byāpādasaṅkappo pahīno hoti, vihiṃsāsaṅkappo pahīno hoti.
dn33:3.3.73.eng: It’s when they’ve given up sensual, malicious, and cruel intentions.

dn33:3.3.74.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu anāvilasaṅkappo hoti.
dn33:3.3.74.eng: That’s how a mendicant has unsullied intentions.

dn33:3.3.75.eng: And how has a mendicant stilled the physical process?

dn33:3.3.76.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
dn33:3.3.76.eng: It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dn33:3.3.77.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu passaddhakāyasaṅkhāro hoti.
dn33:3.3.77.eng: That’s how a mendicant has stilled the physical process.

dn33:3.3.78.eng: And how is a mendicant well freed in mind?

dn33:3.3.79.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno rāgā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, dosā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti, mohā cittaṃ vimuttaṃ hoti.
dn33:3.3.79.eng: It’s when a mendicant’s mind is freed from greed, hate, and delusion.

dn33:3.3.80.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttacitto hoti.
dn33:3.3.80.eng: That’s how a mendicant is well freed in mind.

dn33:3.3.81.eng: And how is a mendicant well freed by wisdom?

dn33:3.3.82.pli: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu ‘rāgo me pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.
dn33:3.3.82.eng: It’s when a mendicant understands: ‘I’ve given up greed, hate, and delusion, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.’

dn33:3.3.83.pli: ‘Doso me pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.

dn33:3.3.84.pli: ‘Moho me pahīno ucchinnamūlo tālāvatthukato anabhāvaṅkato āyatiṃ anuppādadhammo’ti pajānāti.

dn33:3.3.85.pli: Evaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu suvimuttapañño hoti.
dn33:3.3.85.eng: That’s how a mendicant’s mind is well freed by wisdom.

dn33:3.3.87.pli: asekkhā sammādiṭṭhi, asekkho sammāsaṅkappo, asekkhā sammāvācā, asekkho sammākammanto, asekkho sammāājīvo, asekkho sammāvāyāmo, asekkhā sammāsati, asekkho sammāsamādhi, asekkhaṃ sammāñāṇaṃ, asekkhā sammāvimutti.
dn33:3.3.87.eng: an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

dn33:3.3.88.pli: Ime kho, āvuso, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dasa dhammā sammadakkhātā.
dn33:3.3.88.eng: Reverends, these are the teachings grouped by ten that have been rightly explained by the Buddha.

dn33:3.3.89.pli: Tattha sabbeheva saṅgāyitabbaṃ na vivaditabbaṃ, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
dn33:3.3.89.eng: You should all recite these in concert, without disputing, so that this spiritual path may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

dn33:3.4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uṭṭhahitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ āmantesi:
dn33:3.4.1.eng: Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Sāriputta,

dn33:3.4.3.pli: sādhu kho tvaṃ, sāriputta, bhikkhūnaṃ saṅgītipariyāyaṃ abhāsī”ti.
dn33:3.4.3.eng: It’s good that you’ve taught this exposition of the reciting in concert.”

dn33:3.4.4.eng: That is what Venerable Sāriputta said, and the teacher approved.

dn33:3.4.5.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
dn33:3.4.5.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.
